translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I Laud Agni, the chosen Priest, God, minister of sacrifice, The hotar, lavishest of wealth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Worthy is Agni to be praised by living as by ancient seers. He shall bring hitherward the Gods.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Through Agni man obtaineth wealth, yea, plenty waxing day by day, Most rich in heroes, glorious.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni, the perfect sacrifice which thou encompassest about Verily goeth to the Gods.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May Agni, sapient-minded Priest, truthful, most gloriously great, The God, come hither with the Gods.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whatever blessing, Agni, thou wilt grant unto thy worshipper, That, Aṅgiras, is indeed thy truth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To thee, dispeller of the night, O Agni, day by day with prayer Bringing thee reverence, we come

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ruler of sacrifices, guard of Law eternal, radiant One, Increasing in thine own abode.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Be to us easy of approach, even as a father to his son: Agni, be with us for our weal. Next: HYMN II. Vāyu.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: BEAUTIFUL Vāyu, come, for thee these Soma drops have been prepared: Drink of them, hearken to our call.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Knowing the days, with Soma juice poured forth, the singers glorify Thee, Vāyu, with their hymns of praise.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Vāyu, thy penetrating stream goes forth unto the worshipper, Far-spreading for the Soma draught.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: These, Indra-Vāyu, have been shed; come for our offered dainties’ sake: The drops are yearning for you both.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Well do ye mark libations, ye Vāyu and Indra, rich in spoil! So come ye swiftly hitherward.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Vāyu and Indra, come to what the Soma-presser hath prepared: Soon, Heroes, thus I make my prayer.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Mitra, of holy strength, I call, and foe-destroying Varuṇa, Who make the oil-fed rite complete.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Mitra and Varuṇa, through Law, lovers and cherishers of Law, Have ye obtained your might power

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Our Sages, Mitra-Varuṇa, wide dominion, strong by birth, Vouchsafe us strength that worketh well. Next: HYMN III. Aśvins

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: YE Aśvins, rich in treasure, Lords of splendour, having nimble hands, Accept the sacrificial food.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ye Aśvins, rich in wondrous deeds, ye heroes worthy of our praise, Accept our songs with mighty thought.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Nāsatyas, wonder-workers, yours are these libations with clipt grass: Come ye whose paths are red with flame.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indra marvellously bright, come, these libations long for thee, Thus by fine fingers purified.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Urged by the holy singer, sped by song, come, Indra, to the prayers, Of the libation-pouring priest.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Approach, O Indra, hasting thee, Lord of Bay Horses, to the prayers. In our libation take delight.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ye Viśvedevas, who protect, reward, and cherish men, approach Your worshipper's drink-offering.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ye Viśvedevas, swift at work, come hither quickly to the draught, As milch-kine hasten to their stalls.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Viśvedevas, changing shape like serpents, fearless, void of guile, Bearers, accept the sacred draught

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Wealthy in spoil, enriched with hymns, may bright Sarasvatī desire, With eager love, our sacrifice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Inciter of all pleasant songs, inspirer of all gracious thought, Sarasvatī accept our rite

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Sarasvatī, the mighty flood,—she with her light illuminates, She brightens every pious thought. Next: HYMN IV. Indra

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As a good cow to him who milks, we call the doer of fair deeds, To our assistance day by day.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come thou to our libations, drink of Soma; Soma-drinker thou! The rich One's rapture giveth kine.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So may we be acquainted with thine innermost benevolence: Neglect us not, come hitherward.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Go to the wise unconquered One, ask thou of Indra, skilled in song, Him who is better than thy friends.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whether the men who mock us say, Depart unto another place, Ye who serve Indra and none else;

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Or whether, God of wondrous deeds, all our true people call us blest, Still may we dwell in Indra's care.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Unto the swift One bring the swift, man-cheering, grace of sacrifice, That to the Friend gives wings and joy.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou, Śatakratu, drankest this and wast the Vṛtras’ slayer; thou Helpest the warrior in the fray.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We strengthen, Śatakratu, thee, yea, thee the powerful in fight, That, Indra, we may win us wealth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To him the mighty stream of wealth, prompt friend of him who pours the juice, Yea, to this Indra sing your song. Next: HYMN V. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O COME ye hither, sit ye down: to Indra sing ye forth, your song, companions, bringing hymns of praise.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To him the richest of the rich, the Lord of treasures excellent, Indra, with Soma juice outpoured.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May he stand by us in our need and in abundance for our wealth: May he come nigh us with his strength.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whose pair of tawny horses yoked in battles foemen challenge not: To him, to Indra sing your song.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Nigh to the Soma-drinker come, for his enjoyment, these pure drops, The Somas mingled with the curd.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou, grown at once to perfect strength, wast born to drink the Soma juice, Strong Indra, for preëminence.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indra, lover of the song, may these quick Somas enter thee: May they bring bliss to thee the Sage.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Our chants of praise have strengthened thee, O Śatakratu, and our lauds So strengthen thee the songs we sing.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra, whose succour never fails, accept these viands thousandfold, Wherein all manly powers abide.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indra, thou who lovest song, let no man hurt our bodies, keep Slaughter far from us, for thou canst. Next: HYMN VI. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: They who stand round him as he moves harness the bright, the ruddy Steed The lights are shining in the sky.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: On both sides to the car they yoke the two bay coursers dear to him, Bold, tawny, bearers of the Chief.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou, making light where no light was, and form, O men: where form was not, Wast born together with the Dawns.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thereafter they, as is their wont, threw off the state of babes unborn, Assuming sacrificial names.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou, Indra, with the Tempest-Gods, the breakers down of what is firm, Foundest the kine even in the cave.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Worshipping even as they list, singers laud him who findeth wealth, The far-renowned, the mighty One.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Mayest thou verily be seen coming by fearless Indra's side: Both joyous, equal in your sheen.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With Indra's well beloved hosts, the blameless, hastening to heaven, The sacrificer cries aloud.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come from this place, O Wanderer, or downward from the light of heaven: Our songs of praise all yearn for this.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra we seek to give us help, from here, from heaven above the earth, Or from the spacious firmament. Next: HYMN VII. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: INDRA the singers with high praise, Indra reciters with their lauds, Indra the choirs have glorified.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra hath ever close to him his two bay steeds and word-yoked car, Indra the golden, thunder-armed.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra hath raised the Sun on high in heaven, that he may see afar: He burst the mountain for the kine.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Help us, O Indra, in the frays, yea, frays, where thousand spoils are gained, With awful aids, O awful One.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: In mighty battle we invoke Indra, Indra in lesser fight, The Friend who bends his bolt at fiends.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Unclose, our manly Hero, thou for ever bounteous, yonder cloud, For us, thou irresistible.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Still higher, at each strain of mine, thunder-armed Indra's praises rise: I find no laud worthy of him.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Even as the bull drives on the herds, he drives the people with his might, The Ruler irresistible:

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra who rules with single sway men, riches, and the fivefold race Of those who dwell upon the earth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For your sake from each side we call Indra away from other men: Ours, and none others’, may he be. Next: HYMN VIII. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: INDRA, bring wealth that gives delight, the victor's ever-conquering wealth, Most excellent, to be our aid;

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: By means of which we may repel our foes in battle hand to hand, By thee assisted with the car.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Aided by thee, the thunder-armed, Indra, may we lift up the bolt, And conquer all our foes in fight.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With thee, O India, for ally with missile-darting heroes, may We conquer our embattled foes.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Mighty is Indra, yea supreme; greatness be his, the Thunderer: Wide as the heaven extends his power

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Which aideth those to win them sons, who come as heroes to the fight, Or singers loving holy thoughts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: His belly, drinking deepest draughts of Soma, like an ocean swells, Like wide streams from the cope of heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So also is his excellence, great, vigorous, rich in cattle, like A ripe branch to the worshipper.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For verily thy mighty powers, Indra, are saving helps at once Unto a worshipper like me.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So are his lovely gifts; let lauds and praises be to Indra sung, That he may drink the Soma juice. Next: HYMN IX. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: COME, Indra, and delight thee with the juice at all the Soma feasts, Protector, mighty in thy strength.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To Indra pour ye forth the juice, the active gladdening juice to him The gladdening, omnific God.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Lord of all men, fair of cheek, rejoice thee in the gladdening lauds, Present at these drink-offerings.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Songs have outpoured themselves to thee, Indra, the strong, the guardian Lord, And raised themselves unsatisfied.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Send to us bounty manifold, O Indra, worthy of our wish, For power supreme is only thine.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indra, stimulate thereto us emulously fain for wealth, And glorious, O most splendid One.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Give, Indra, wide and lofty fame, wealthy in cattle and in strength, Lasting our life-time, failing not.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Grant us high fame, O Indra, grant riches bestowing thousands, those Fair fruits of earth borne home in wains.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Praising with songs the praise-worthy who cometh to our aid, we call Indra, the Treasure-Lord of wealth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To lofty Indra, dweller by each libation, the pious man Sings forth aloud a strengthening hymn. Next: HYMN X. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: THE chanters hymn thee, they who say the word of praise magnify thee. The priests have raised thee up on high, O Śatakratu, like a pole.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As up he clomb from ridge to ridge and looked upon the toilsome task, Indra observes this wish of his, and the Rain hastens with his troop.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Harness thy pair of strong bay steeds, long-maned, whose bodies fill the girths, And, Indra, Soma-drinker, come to listen to our songs of praise.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come hither, answer thou the song, sing in approval, cry aloud. Good Indra, make our prayer succeed, and prosper this our sacrifice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To Indra must a laud be said, to strengthen him who freely gives, That Śakra may take pleasure in our friendship and drink-offerings.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Him, him we seek for friendship, him for riches and heroic might. For Indra, he is Śakra, he shall aid us while he gives us wealth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Easy to turn and drive away, Indra, is spoil bestowed by thee. Unclose the stable of the kine, and give us wealth O Thunder-armed

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The heaven and earth contain thee not, together, in thy wrathful mood. Win us the waters of the sky, and send us kine abundantly.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Hear, thou whose ear is quick, my call; take to thee readily my songs O Indra, let this laud of mine come nearer even than thy friend.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We know thee mightiest of all, in battles hearer of our cry. Of thee most mighty we invoke the aid that giveth thousandfold.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indra, Son of Kuśika, drink our libation with delight. Prolong our life anew, and cause the seer to win a thousand gifts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Lover of song, may these our songs on every side encompass thee: Strengthening thee of lengthened life, may they be dear delights to thee. Next: HYMN XI. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: ALL sacred songs have magnified Indra expansive as the sea, The best of warriors borne on cars, the Lord, the very Lord of strength.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Strong in thy friendship, Indra, Lord of power and might, we have no fear. We glorify with praises thee, the never-conquered conqueror.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The gifts of Indra from of old, his saving succours, never fail, When to the praise-singers he gives the boon of substance rich in kine.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Crusher of forts, the young, the wise, of strength unmeasured, was he born Sustainer of each sacred rite, Indra, the Thunderer, much-extolled.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Lord of the thunder, thou didst burst the cave of Vala rich in cows. The Gods came pressing to thy side, and free from terror aided thee,

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I, Hero, through thy bounties am come to the flood addressing thee. Song-lover, here the singers stand and testify to thee thereof.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The wily Śuṣṇa, Indra! thou o’erthrewest with thy wondrous powers. The wise beheld this deed of thine: now go beyond their eulogies.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Our songs of praise have glorified Indra who ruleth by his might, Whose precious gifts in thousands come, yea, even more abundantly. Next: HYMN XII. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: WE choose Agni the messenger, the herald, master of all wealth, Well skilled in this our sacrifice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With callings ever they invoke Agni, Agni, Lord of the House, Oblation-bearer, much beloved.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Bring the Gods hither, Agni, born for him who strews the sacred grass: Thou art our herald, meet for praise.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Wake up the willing Gods, since thou, Agni, performest embassage: Sit on the sacred grass with Gods.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Agni, radiant One, to whom the holy oil is poured, burn up Our enemies whom fiends protect.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: By Agni Agni is inflamed, Lord of the House, wise, young, who bears The gift: the ladle is his mouth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Praise Agni in the sacrifice, the Sage whose ways are ever true, The God who driveth grief away.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: God, Agni, be his strong defence who lord of sacrificial gifts, Worshippeth thee the messenger.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whoso with sacred gift would fain call Agni to the feast of Gods, O Purifier, favour him.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Such, Agni, Purifier, bright, bring hither to our sacrifice, To our oblation bring the Gods.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So lauded by our newest song of praise bring opulence to us, And food, with heroes for our sons.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Agni, by effulgent flame, by all invokings of the Gods, Show pleasure in this laud of ours. Next: HYMN XIII. Agni

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: AGNI, well-kindled, bring the Gods for him who offers holy gifts. Worship them, Purifier, Priest.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Son of Thyself, present, O Sage, our sacrifice to the Gods today. Sweet to the taste, that they may feast.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Dear Narāśaṁsa, sweet of tongue, the giver of oblations, I Invoke to this our sacrifice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni, on thy most easy car, glorified, hither bring the Gods: Manu appointed thee as Priest.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Strew, O ye wise, the sacred grass that drips with oil, in order due, Where the Immortal is beheld.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thrown open be the Doors Divine, unfailing, that assist the rite, For sacrifice this day and now.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I call the lovely Night and Dawn to seat them on the holy grass At this our solemn sacrifice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The two Invokers I invite, the wise, divine and sweet of tongue, To celebrate this our sacrifice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Iḷā, Sarasvatī, Mahī, three Goddesses who bring delight, Be seated, peaceful, on the grass.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Tvaṣṭar I call, the earliest born, the wearer of all forms at will: May he be ours and ours alone.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: God, Sovran of the Wood, present this our oblation to the Gods, And let the giver be renowned.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With Svāhā pay the sacrifice to Indra in the offerer's house: Thither I call the Deities. Next: HYMN XIV. Viśvedevas.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To drink the Soma, Agni, come, to our service and our songs. With all these Gods; and worship them.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Kaṇvas have invoked thee; they, O Singer, sing thee songs of praise Agni, come hither with the Gods;

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra, Vāyu, Bṛhaspati, Mitra, Agni, Pūṣan, Bhaga, Ādityas, and the Marut host.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For you these juices are poured forth that gladden and exhilarate, The meath-drops resting in the cup.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The sons of Kaṇva fain for help adore thee, having strewn the grass, With offerings and all things prepared.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Let the swift steeds who carry thee, thought-yoked and dropping holy oil, Bring the Gods to the Soma draught.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Adored, the strengtheners of Law, unite them, Agni, with their Dames: Make them drink meath, O bright of tongue.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Let them, O Agni, who deserve worship and praise drink with thy tongue The meath in solemn sacrifice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Away, from the Sun's realm of light, the wise invoking Priest shall bring All Gods awaking with the dawn.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With all the Gods, with Indra, with Vāyu, and Mitra's splendours, drink, Agni, the pleasant Soma juice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ordained by Manu as our Priest, thou sittest, Agni, at each rite: Hallow thou this our sacrifice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Harness the Red Mares to thy car, the Bays, O God, the flaming ones: With those bring hitherward the Gods. Next: HYMN XV. Ṛtu.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O INDRA drink the Soma juice with Ṛtu; let the cheering drops Sink deep within, which settle there.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Drink from the Purifier's cup, Maruts, with Ṛtu; sanctify The rite, for ye give precious gifts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Neṣṭar, with thy Dame accept our sacrifice; with Ṛtu drink, For thou art he who giveth wealth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Bring the Gods, Agni; in the three appointed places set them down: Surround them, and with Ṛtu drink.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Drink Soma after the Ṛtus, from the Brāhmaṇa's bounty: undissolved, O Indra, is thy friendship's bond.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Mitra, Varuṇa, ye whose ways are firm—a Power that none deceives—, With Ṛtu ye have reached the rite.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Soma-pressers, fain for wealth, praise the Wealth-giver in the rite, In sacrifices praise the God.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May the Wealth-giver grant to us riches that shall be far renowned. These things we gain, among the Gods.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He with the Ṛtu fain would drink, Wealth-giver, from the Neṣṭar's bowl. Haste, give your offering, and depart.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As we this fourth time, Wealth-giver, honour thee with the Ṛtus, be A Giver bountiful to us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Drink ye the meath, O Aśvins bright with flames, whose acts are pure, who with Ṛtus accept the sacrifice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With Ṛtu, through the house-fire, thou, kind Giver, guidest sacrifice: Worship the Gods for the pious man. Next: HYMN XVI. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: LET thy Bay Steeds bring thee, the Strong, hither to drink the Soma draught— Those, Indra, who are bright as suns.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Here are the grains bedewed with oil: hither let the Bay Coursers bring Indra upon his easiest car.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra at early morn we call, Indra in course of sacrifice, Indra to drink the Soma juice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come hither, with thy long-maned Steeds, O Indra, to he draught we pour We call thee when the juice is shed.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come thou to this our song of praise, to the libation poured for thee Drink of it like a stag athirst.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Here are the drops of Soma juice expressed on sacred grass: thereof Drink, Indra, to increase thy might.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Welcome to thee be this our hymn, reaching thy heart, most excellent: Then drink the Soma juice expressed.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To every draught of pressed-out juice Indra, the Vṛtra-slayer, comes, To drink the Soma for delight.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Fulfil, O Śatakratu, all our wish with horses and with kine: With holy thoughts we sing thy praise. Next: HYMN XVII. Indra-Varuṇa

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I CRAVE help from the Imperial Lords, from Indra-Varuṇa; may they Both favour one of us like me.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Guardians of men, ye ever come with ready succour at the call Of every singer such as I.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Sate you, according to your wish, O Indra-Varuṇa, with wealth: Fain would we have you nearest us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May we be sharers of the powers, sharers of the benevolence Of you who give strength bounteously.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra and Varuṇa, among givers of thousands, meet for praise, Are Powers who merit highest laud.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Through their protection may we gain great store of wealth, and heap it up Enough and still to spare, be ours.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indra-Varuṇa, on you for wealth in many a form I call: Still keep ye us victorious.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indra-Varuṇa, through our songs that seek to win you to ourselves, Give us at once your sheltering help.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indra-Varuṇa, to you may fair praise which I offer come, Joint eulogy which ye dignify. Next: HYMN XVIII. Brahmaṇaspati.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O BRĀHMAṆASPATI, make him who presses Soma glorious, Even Kakṣīvān Auśija.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The rich, the healer of disease, who giveth wealth, increaseth store, The prompt,—may he be with us still.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Let not the foeman's curse, let not a mortal's onslaught fall on us Preserve us, Brahmaṇaspati.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ne’er is the mortal hero harmed whom Indra, Brahmaṇaspati, And Soma graciously inspire.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Do, thou, O Brahmaṇaspati, and Indra, Soma, Dakṣiṇā, Preserve that mortal from distress.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To the Assembly's wondrous Lord, to Indra's lovely Friend who gives Wisdom, have I drawn near in prayer.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He without whom no sacrifice, e’en of the wise man, prospers; he Stirs up the series of thoughts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He makes the oblation prosper, he promotes the course of sacrifice: Our voice of praise goes to the Gods.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I have seen Narāśaṁsa, him most resolute, most widely famed, As ’twere the Household Priest of heaven. Next: HYMN XIX. Agni, Maruts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To this fair sacrifice to drink the milky draught thou art invoked: O Agni, with the Maruts come.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: No mortal man, no God exceeds thy mental power, O Mighty one: O Agni, with the Maruts come:

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: All Gods devoid of guile, who know the mighty region of mid-air: O Agni, with those Maruts come.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The terrible, who sing their song, not to be overcome by might: O Agni, with those Maruts come.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Brilliant, and awful in their form, mighty, devourers of their foes: O Agni, with those Maruts come.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Who sit as Deities in heaven, above the sky-vault's luminous sphere: O Agni, with those Maruts come.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Who scatter clouds about the sky, away over the billowy sea: O Agni, with those Maruts come.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Who with their bright beams spread them forth over the ocean in their might O Agni, with those Maruts come.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For thee, to be thine early draught, I pour the Soma-mingled meath: O Agni, with the Maruts come. Next: HYMN XX. Ṛbhus.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: FOR the Celestial Race this song of praise which gives wealth lavishly Was made by singers with their lips.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: They who for Indra, with their mind, formed horses harnessed by a word, Attained by works to sacrifice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: They for the two Nāsatyas wrought a light car moving every way: They formed a nectar-yielding cow.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Ṛbhus with effectual prayers, honest, with constant labour, made Their Sire and Mother young again.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Together came your gladdening drops with Indra by the Maruts girt, With the Ādityas, with the Kings.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The sacrificial ladle, wrought newly by the God Tvaṣṭar's hand— Four ladles have ye made thereof.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Vouchsafe us wealth, to him who pours thrice seven libations, yea, to each Give wealth, pleased with our eulogies.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As ministering Priests they held, by pious acts they won themselves, A share in sacrifice with Gods. Next: HYMN XXI. Indra-Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: INDRA and Agni I invoke fain are we for their song of praise: Chief Soma-drinkers are they both.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Praise ye, O men, and glorify Indra-Agni in the holy rites: Sing praise to them in sacred songs.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra and Agni we invite, the Soma-drinkers, for the fame Of Mitra, to the Soma-draught.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Strong Gods, we bid them come to this libation that stands ready here: Indra and Agni, come to us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra and Agni, mighty Lords of our assembly, crush the fiends: Childless be the devouring ones.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Watch ye, through this your truthfulness, there in the place of spacious view Indra and Agni, send us bliss. Next: HYMN XXII. Aśvins and Others

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: WAKEN the Aśvin Pair who yoke their car at early morn: may they Approach to drink this Soma juice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We call the Aśvins Twain, the Gods borne in a noble car, the best Of charioteers, who reach the heavens.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Dropping with honey is your whip, Aśvins, and full of pleasantness Sprinkle therewith the sacrifice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As ye go thither in your car, not far, O Aśvins, is the home Of him who offers Soma juice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For my protection I invoke the golden-handed Savitar. He knoweth, as a God, the place.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: That he may send us succour, praise the Waters’ Offspring Savitar: Fain are we for his holy ways.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We call on him, distributer of wondrous bounty and of wealth, On Savitar who looks on men.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come hither, friends, and seat yourselves Savitar, to be praised by us, Giving good gifts, is beautiful.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Agni, hither bring to us the willing Spouses of the Gods, And Tvaṣṭar, to the Soma draught.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Most youthful Agni, hither bring their Spouses, Hotrā, Bhāratī, Varūtrī, Dhiṣaṇā, for aid.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Spouses of Heroes, Goddesses, with whole wings may they come to us With great protection and with aid.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indrāṇī, Varuṇānī, and Agnāyī hither I invite, For weal, to drink the Soma juice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May Heaven and Earth, the Mighty Pair, bedew for us our sacrifice, And feed us full with nourishments.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Their water rich with fatness, there in the Gandharva's steadfast place, The singers taste through sacred songs.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thornless be thou, O Earth, spread wide before us for a dwelling-place: Vouchsafe us shelter broad and sure.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Gods be gracious unto us even from the place whence Viṣṇu strode Through the seven regions of the earth!

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Through all this world strode Viṣṇu; thrice his foot he planted, and the whole Was gathered in his footstep's dust.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Viṣṇu, the Guardian, he whom none deceiveth, made three steps; thenceforth Establishing his high decrees.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Look ye on Viṣṇu's works, whereby the Friend of Indra, close-allied, Hath let his holy ways be seen.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The princes evermore behold that loftiest place where Viṣṇu is, Laid as it were an eye in heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This, Viṣṇu's station most sublime, the singers, ever vigilant, Lovers of holy song, light up. Next: HYMN XXIII. Vāyu and Others.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: STRONG are the Somas; come thou nigh; these juices have been mixt with milk: Drink, Vāyu, the presented draughts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Both Deities who touch the heaven, Indra and Vāyu we invoke To drink of this our Soma juice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The singers' for their aid, invoke Indra and Vāyu, swift as mind, The thousand-eyed, the Lords of thought.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Mitra and Varuṇa, renowned as Gods of consecrated might, We call to drink the Soma juice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Those who by Law uphold the Law, Lords of the shining light of Law, Mitra I call, and Varuṇa.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Let Varuṇa be our chief defence, let Mitra guard us with all aids Both make us rich exceedingly.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra, by Maruts girt, we call to drink the Soma juice: may he Sate him in union with his troop.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Gods, Marut hosts whom Indra leads, distributers of Pūṣan's gifts, Hearken ye all unto my cry.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With conquering Indra for ally, strike Vṛtra down, ye bounteous Gods Let not the wicked master us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We call the Universal Gods, and Maruts to the Soma draught, For passing strong are Pṛśni's Sons.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Fierce comes the Maruts’ thundering voice, like that of conquerors, when ye go Forward to victory, O Men.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Born of the laughing lightning. may the Maruts guard us everywhere May they be gracious unto Us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Like some lost animal, drive to us, bright Pūṣan, him who bears up heaven, Resting on many-coloured grass.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Pūṣan the Bright has found the King, concealed and hidden in a cave, Who rests on grass of many hues.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: And may he. duly bring to me the six bound closely, through these drops, As one who ploughs with steers brings corn.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Along their paths the Mothers go, Sisters of priestly ministrants, Mingling their sweetness with the milk.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May Waters gathered near the Sun, and those wherewith the Sun is joined, Speed forth this sacrifice of ours.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I call the Waters, Goddesses, wherein our cattle quench their thirst; Oblations to the Streams be given.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Amrit is in the Waters in the Waters there is healing balm Be swift, ye Gods, to give them praise.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Within the Waters—Soma thus hath told me—dwell all balms that heal, And Agni, he who blesseth all. The Waters hold all medicines.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Waters, teem with medicine to keep my body safe from harm, So that I long may see the Sun.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whatever sin is found in me, whatever evil I have wrought. If I have lied or falsely sworn, Waters, remove it far from me.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Waters I this day have sought, and to their moisture have we come: O Agni, rich in milk, come thou, and with thy splendour cover me.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Fill me with splendour, Agni; give offspring and length of days; the Gods Shall know me even as I am, and Indra with the Ṛṣis, know. Next: HYMN XXIV. Varuṇa and Others.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: WHO now is he, what God among Immortals, of whose auspicious name we may bethink us? Who shall to mighty Aditi restore us, that I may see my Father and my Mother?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni the God the first among the Immortals,—of his auspicious name let us bethink us. He shall to mighty Aditi restore us, that I may see my Father and my Mother.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To thee, O Savitar, the Lord of precious things, who helpest us Continually, for our share we come—

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Wealth, highly lauded ere reproach hath fallen on it, which is laid, Free from all hatred, in thy hands

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Through thy protection may we come to even the height of affluence Which Bhaga hath dealt out to us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ne’er have those birds that fly through air attained to thy high dominion or thy might or spirit; Nor these the waters that flow on for ever, nor hills, abaters of the wind's wild fury.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Varuṇa, King, of hallowed might, sustaineth erect the Tree's stem in the baseless region. Its rays, whose root is high above, stream downward. Deep may they sink within us, and be hidden.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: King Varuṇa hath made a spacious pathway, a pathway for the Sun wherein to travel. Where no way was he made him set his footstep, and warned afar whate’er afflicts the spirit.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: A hundred balms are thine, O King, a thousand; deep and wide-reaching also be thy favours. Far from us, far away drive thou Destruction. Put from us e’en the sin we have committed.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whither by day depart the constellations that shine at night, set high in heaven above us? Varuṇa's holy laws remain unweakened, and through the night the Moon moves on in splendor

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I ask this of thee with my prayer adoring; thy worshipper craves this with his oblation. Varuṇa, stay thou here and be not angry; steal not our life from us, O thou Wide-Ruler.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Nightly and daily this one thing they tell me, this too the thought of mine own heart repeateth. May he to whom prayed fettered Śunaḥśepa, may he the Sovran Varuṇa release us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Bound to three pillars captured Śunaḥśepa thus to the Āditya made his supplication. Him may the Sovran Varuṇa deliver, wise, ne’er deceived, loosen the bonds that bind him.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With bending down, oblations, sacrifices, O Varuṇa, we deprecate thine anger: Wise Asura, thou King of wide dominion, loosen the bonds of sins by us committed.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Loosen the bonds, O Varuṇa, that hold me, loosen the bonds above, between, and under. So in thy holy law may we made sinless belong to Aditi, O thou Āditya. Next: HYMN XXV. Varuṇa.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: WHATEVER law of thine, O God, O Varuṇa, as we are men, Day after day we violate.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: give us not as a prey to death, to be destroyed by thee in wrath, To thy fierce anger when displeased.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To gain thy mercy, Varuṇa, with hymns we bind thy heart, as binds The charioteer his tethered horse.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: They flee from me dispirited, bent only on obtaining wealth, As to their nests the birds of air.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When shall we bring, to be appeased, the Hero, Lord of warrior might, Him, the far-seeing Varuṇa?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This, this with joy they both accept in common: never do they fail The ever-faithful worshipper.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He knows the path of birds that fly through heaven, and, Sovran of the sea, He knows the ships that are thereon.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: True to his holy law, he knows the twelve moons with their progeny: He knows the moon of later birth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He knows the pathway of the wind, the spreading, high, and mighty wind: He knows the Gods who dwell above.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Varuṇa, true to holy law, sits down among his people; he, Most wise, sits there to govern all.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: From thence perceiving he beholds all wondrous things, both what hath been, And what hereafter will be done.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May that Āditya, very wise, make fair paths for us all our days: May he prolong our lives for us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Varuṇa, wearing golden mail, hath clad him in a shining robe. His spies are seated found about.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The God whom enemies threaten not, nor those who tyrannize o’er men, Nor those whose minds are bent on wrong.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He who gives glory to mankind, not glory that is incomplete, To our own bodies giving it.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Yearning for the wide-seeing One, my thoughts move onward unto him, As kine unto their pastures move.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Once more together let us speak, because my meath is brought: priest-like Thou eatest what is dear to thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Now saw I him whom all may see, I saw his car above the earth: He hath accepted these my songs.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Varuṇa, hear this call of mine: be gracious unto us this day Longing for help I cried to thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou, O wise God, art Lord of all, thou art the King of earth and heaven Hear, as thou goest on thy way.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Release us from the upper bond, untie the bond between, and loose The bonds below, that I may live. Next: HYMN XXVI. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O WORTHY of oblation, Lord of prospering powers, assume thy robes, And offer this our sacrifice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Sit ever to be chosen, as our Priest, most youthful, through our hymns, O Agni, through our heavenly word.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For here a Father for his son, Kinsman for kinsman worshippeth, And Friend, choice-worthy, for his friend.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Here let the foe-destroyers sit, Varuṇa, Mitra, Aryaman, Like men, upon our sacred grass.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O ancient Herald, be thou glad in this our rite and fellowship: Hearken thou well to these our songs.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whate’er in this perpetual course we sacrifice to God and God, That gift is offered up in thee

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May he be our dear household Lord, Priest, pleasant and, choice-worthy may We, with bright fires, be dear to him.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Gods, adored with brilliant fires. have granted precious wealth to us So, with bright fires, we pray to thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: And, O Immortal One, so may the eulogies of mortal men Belong to us and thee alike.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With all thy fires, O Agni, find pleasure in this our sacrifice, And this our speech, O Son of Strength. Next: HYMN XXVII. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: WITH worship will I glorify thee, Agni, like a long-tailed steed, Imperial Lord of sacred rites.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May the far-striding Son of Strength, bringer of great felicity, Who pours his gifts like rain, be ours.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Lord of all life, from near; from far, do thou, O Agni evermore Protect us from the sinful man.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Agni, graciously announce this our oblation to the Gods, And this our newest song of praise.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Give us a share of strength most high, a share of strength that is below, A share of strength that is between.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou dealest gifts, resplendent One; nigh, as with waves of Sindhu, thou Swift streamest to the worshipper.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: That man is lord of endless strength whom thou protectest in the fight, Agni, or urgest to the fray.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Him, whosoever he may be, no man may vanquish, mighty One: Nay, very glorious power is his.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May he who dwells with all mankind bear us with war-steeds through the fight, And with the singers win the spoil.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Help, thou who knowest lauds, this work, this eulogy to Rudra, him Adorable in every house.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May this our God, great, limitless, smoke-bannered excellently bright, Urge us to strength and holy thought.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Like some rich Lord of men may he, Agni the banner of the Gods, Refulgent, hear us through our lauds.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Glory to Gods, the mighty and the lesser glory to Gods the younger and the elder! Let us, if we have power, pay the God worship: no better prayer than this, ye Gods, acknowledge. Next: HYMN XXVIII. Indra, Etc.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: THERE where the broad-based stone raised on high to press the juices out, O Indra, drink with eager thirst the droppings which the mortar sheds.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Where, like broad hips, to hold the juice the platters of the press are laid, O Indra, drink with eager thirst the droppings which the mortar sheds.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: There where the woman marks and leans the pestle's constant rise and fall, O Indra, drink with eager thirst the droppings which the mortar sheds.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Where, as with reins to guide a horse, they bind the churning-staff with cords, O Indra, drink with eager thirst the droppings which the mortar sheds.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: If of a truth in every house, O Mortar thou art set for work, Here give thou forth thy clearest sound, loud as the drum of conquerors.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Sovran of the Forest, as the wind blows soft in front of thee, Mortar, for Indra press thou forth the Soma juice that he may drink.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Best strength-givers, ye stretch wide jaws, O Sacrificial Implements, Like two bay horses champing herbs.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ye Sovrans of the Forest, both swift, with swift pressers press to-day Sweet Soma juice for Indra's drink.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Take up in beakers what remains: the Soma on the filter pour, and on the ox-hide set the dregs. Next: HYMN XXIX. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O SOMA DRINKER, ever true, utterly hopeless though we be, Do thou, O Indra, give us hope of beauteous horses and of kine, In thousands, O most wealthy One.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Lord of Strength, whose jaws are strong, great deeds are thine, the powerful: Do thou, O Indra, give us hope of beauteous horses and of kine, In thousands, O most wealthy One.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Lull thou asleep, to wake no more, the pair who on each other look Do thou, O Indra, give us hope of beauteous horses and of kine, In thousands, O most wealthy One.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Hero, let hostile spirits sleep, and every gentler genius wake: Do thou, O Indra, give us hope of beauteous horses and of kine, In thousands, O most wealthy One.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Destroy this ass, O Indra, who in tones discordant brays to thee: Do thou, O Indra, give us hope of beauteous horses and of kine, In thousands, O most wealthy One.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Far distant on the forest fall the tempest in a circling course! Do thou, O Indra, give us hope of beauteous horses and of kine, In thousands, O most wealthy One.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Slay each reviler, and destroy him who in secret injures us: Do thou, O Indra, give us hope of beauteous horses and of kine In thousands, O most wealthy One. Next: HYMN XXX. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: WE seeking strength with Soma-drops fill full your Indra like a well, Most liberal, Lord of Hundred Powers,

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Who lets a hundred of the pure, a thousand of the milk-blent draughts Flow, even as down a depth, to him;

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When for the strong, the rapturous joy he in this manner hath made room Within his belly, like the sea.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This is thine own. Thou drawest near, as turns a pigeon to his mate: Thou carest too for this our prayer.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Hero, Lord of Bounties, praised in hymns, may power and joyfulness Be his who sings the laud to thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Lord of a Hundred Powers, stand up to lend us succour in this fight In others too let us agree.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: In every need, in every fray we call as friends to succour us Indra the mightiest of all.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: If he will hear us let him come with succour of a thousand kinds, And all that strengthens, to our call.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I call him mighty to resist, the Hero of our ancient home, Thee whom my sire invoked of old.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We pray to thee, O much-invoked, rich in all precious gifts, O Friend, Kind God to those who sing thy praise.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Soma-drinker, Thunder-armed, Friend of our lovely-featured dames And of our Soma-drinking friends.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thus, Soma-drinker, may it be; thus, Friend, who wieldest thunder, act To aid each wish as we desire.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With Indra splendid feasts be ours, rich in all strengthening things wherewith, Wealthy in food, we may rejoice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Like thee, thyself, the singers' Friend, thou movest, as it were, besought, Bold One, the axle of the car.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: That, Śatakratu, thou to grace and please thy praisers, as it were, Stirrest the axle with thy strength.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With champing, neighing loudly-snorting horses Indra hath ever won himself great treasures A car of gold hath he whose deeds are wondrous received from us, and let us too receive it.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come, Aśvins, with enduring strength wealthy in horses and in kine, And gold, O ye of wondrous deeds.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Your chariot yoked for both alike, immortal, ye of mighty acts, Travels, O Aśvins, in the sea.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: High on the forehead of the Bull one chariot wheel ye ever keep, The other round the sky revolves.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: What mortal, O immortal Dawn, enjoyeth thee? Where lovest thou? To whom, O radiant, dost thou go?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For we have had thee in our thoughts whether anear or far away, Red-hued and like a dappled mare.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Hither, O Daughter of the Sky, come thou with these thy strengthenings, And send thou riches down to us. Next: HYMN XXXI. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou, Agni, wast the earliest Aṅgiras, a Seer; thou wast, a God thyself, the Gods’ auspicious Friend. After thy holy ordinance the Maruts, sage, active through wisdom, with their glittering spears, were born.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Agni, thou, the best and earliest Aṅgiras, fulfillest as a Sage the holy law of Gods. Sprung from two mothers, wise, through all existence spread, resting in many a place for sake of living man.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To Mātariśvan first thou, Agni, wast disclosed, and to Vivasvān through thy noble inward power. Heaven and Earth, Vasu! shook at the choosing of the Priest: the burthen thou didst bear, didst worship mighty Gods.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni thou madest heaven to thunder for mankind; thou, yet more pious, for pious Purūravas. When thou art rapidly freed from thy parents, first eastward they bear thee round, and, after, to the west.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou, Agni, art a Bull who makes our store increase, to be invoked by him who lifts the ladle up. Well knowing the oblation with the hallowing word, uniting all who live, thou lightenest first our folk

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni, thou savest in the synod when pursued e’en him, farseeing One! who walks in evil ways. Thou, when the heroes fight for spoil which men rush, round, slayest in war the many by the hands of few.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For glory, Agni, day by day, thou liftest up the mortal man to highest immortality, Even thou who yearning for both races givest them great bliss, and to the prince grantest abundant food.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Agni, highly lauded, make our singer famous that he may win us store of riches: May we improve the rite with new performance. O Earth and Heaven, with all the Gods, protect us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O blameless Agni lying in thy Parents' lap, a God among the Gods, be watchful for our good. Former of bodies, be the singer's Providence: all good things hast thou sown for him, auspicious One!

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni, thou art our Providence, our Father thou: we are thy brethren and thou art our spring of life. In thee, rich in good heroes, guard of high decrees, meet hundred, thousand treasures, O infallible!

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thee, Agni, have the Gods made the first living One for living man, Lord of the house of Nahuṣa. Iḷā they made the teacher of the sons of men, what time a Son was born to the father of my race.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Worthy to be revered, O Agni, God, preserve our wealthy patrons with thy succours, and ourselves. Guard of our seed art thou, aiding our cows to bear, incessantly protecting in thy holy way.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni, thou art a guard close to the pious man; kindled art thou, four-eyed! for him who is unarmed. With fond heart thou acceptest e’en the poor man's prayer, when he hath brought his gift to gain security.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou, Agni gainest for the loudly-praising priest the highest wealth, the object of a man's desire. Thou art called Father, caring even for the weak, and wisest, to the simple one thou teachest lore.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni, the man who giveth guerdon to the priests, like well-sewn armour thou guardest on every side. He who with grateful food shows kindness in his house, an offerer to the living, is the type of heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Pardon, we pray, this sin of ours, O Agni,—the path which we have trodden, widely straying, Dear Friend and Father, caring for the pious, who speedest nigh and who inspirest mortals.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As erst to Manus, to Yayāti, Aṅgiras, so Aṅgiras! pure Agni! come thou to our hall. Bring hither the celestial host and seat them here upon the sacred grass, and offer what they love.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: By this our prayer be thou, O Agni, strengthened, prayer made by us after our power and knowledge. Lead thou us, therefore, to increasing riches; endow us with thy strength-bestowing favour. Next: HYMN XXXII. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I WILL declare the manly deeds of Indra, the first that he achieved, the Thunder-wielder. He slew the Dragon, then disclosed the waters, and cleft the channels of the mountain torrents.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He slew the Dragon lying on the mountain: his heavenly bolt of thunder Tvaṣṭar fashioned. Like lowing kine in rapid flow descending the waters glided downward to the ocean.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Impetuous as a bull, he chose the Soma and in three sacred beakers drank the juices. Maghavan grasped the thunder for his weapon, and smote to death this firstborn of the dragons.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When, Indra, thou hadst slain the dragon's firstborn, and overcome the charms of the enchanters, Then, giving life to Sun and Dawn and Heaven, thou foundest not one foe to stand against thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra with his own great and deadly thunder smote into pieces Vṛtra, worst of Vṛtras. As trunks of trees, what time the axe hath felled them, low on the earth so lies the prostrate Dragon.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He, like a mad weak warrior, challenged Indra, the great impetuous many-slaying Hero. He, brooking not the clashing of the weapons, crushed—Indra's foe—the shattered forts in falling.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Footless and handless still he challenged Indra, who smote him with his bolt between the shoulders. Emasculate yet claiming manly vigour, thus Vṛtra lay with scattered limbs dissevered.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: There as he lies like a bank-bursting river, the waters taking courage flow above him. The Dragon lies beneath the feet of torrents which Vṛtra with his greatness had encompassed.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Then humbled was the strength of Vṛtra's mother: Indra hath cast his deadly bolt against her. The mother was above, the son was under and like a cow beside her calf lay Danu.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Rolled in the midst of never-ceasing currents flowing without a rest for ever onward. The waters bear off Vṛtra's nameless body: the foe of Indra sank to during darkness.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Guarded by Ahi stood the thralls of Dāsas, the waters stayed like kine held by the robber. But he, when he had smitten Vṛtra, opened the cave wherein the floods had been imprisoned.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: A horse's tail wast thou when he, O Indra, smote on thy bolt; thou, God without a second, Thou hast won back the kine, hast won the Soma; thou hast let loose to flow the Seven Rivers.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Nothing availed him lightning, nothing thunder, hailstorm or mist which had spread around him: When Indra and the Dragon strove in battle, Maghavan gained the victory for ever.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whom sawest thou to avenge the Dragon, Indra, that fear possessed thy heart when thou hadst slain him; That, like a hawk affrighted through the regions, thou crossedst nine-and-ninety flowing rivers?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra is King of all that moves and moves not, of creatures tame and horned, the Thunder-wielder. Over all living men he rules as Sovran, containing all as spokes within the felly. Next: HYMN XXXIII. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come, fain for booty let us seek to Indra: yet more shall he increase his care that guides us. Will not the Indestructible endow us with perfect knowledge of this wealth, of cattle?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I fly to him invisible Wealth-giver as flies the falcon to his cherished eyrie, With fairest hymns of praise adoring Indra, whom those who laud him must invoke in battle.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Mid all his host, he bindeth on the quiver: he driveth cattle from what foe he pleaseth: Gathering up great store of riches, Indra. be thou no trafficker with us, most mighty.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou slewest with thy bolt the wealthy Dasyu, alone, yet going with thy helpers, Indra! Far from the floor of heaven in all directions, the ancient riteless ones fled to destruction.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Fighting with pious worshippers, the riteless turned and fled, Indra! with averted faces. When thou, fierce Lord of the Bay Steeds, the Stayer, blewest from earth and heaven and sky the godless.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: They met in fight the army of the blameless: then the Navagvas put forth all their power. They, like emasculates with men contending, fled, conscious, by steep paths from Indra, scattered.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whether they weep or laugh, thou hast o’erthrown them, O Indra, on the sky's extremest limit. The Dasyu thou hast burned from heaven, and welcomed the prayer of him who pours the juice and lauds thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Adorned with their array of gold and jewels, they o’er the earth a covering veil extended. Although they hastened, they o’ercame not Indra: their spies he compassed with the Sun of morning.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As thou enjoyest heaven and earth, O Indra, on every side surrounded with thy greatness, So thou with priests hast blown away the Dasyu, and those who worship not with those who worship.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: They who pervaded earth's extremest limit subdued not with their charms the Wealth-bestower: Indra, the Bull, made his ally the thunder, and with its light milked cows from out the darkness.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The waters flowed according to their nature; he raid the navigable streams waxed mighty. Then Indra, with his spirit concentrated, smote him for ever with his strongest weapon.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra broke through Ilībiśa's strong castles, and Śuṣṇa with his horn he cut to pieces: Thou, Maghavan, for all his might and swiftness, slewest thy fighting foeman with thy thunder

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Fierce on his enemies fell Indra's weapon: with. his sharp bull he rent their forts in pieces. He with his thunderbolt dealt blows on Vṛtra; and conquered, executing all his purpose.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra, thou helpest Kutsa whom thou lovedst, and guardedst brave Daśadyu when he battled, The dust of trampling horses rose to heaven, and Śvitrā's son stood up again for conquest.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Śvitrā's mild steer, O Maghavan thou helpest in combat for the land, mid Tugra's houses. Long stood they there before the task was ended: thou wast the master of the foemen's treasure. Next: HYMN XXXIV. Aśvins.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ye who observe this day be with us even thrice: far-stretching is you bounty, Aśvins and your course. To you, as to a cloak in winter, we cleave close: you are to be drawn nigh unto us by the wise.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Three are the fellies in your honey-bearing car, that travels after Soma's loved one, as all know. Three are the pillars set upon it for support: thrice journey ye by night, O Aśvins, thrice by day.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thrice in the self-same day, ye Gods who banish want, sprinkle ye thrice to-day our sacrifice with meath; And thrice vouchsafe us store of food with plenteous strength, at evening, O ye Aśvins, and at break of day.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thrice come ye to our home, thrice to the righteous folk, thrice triply aid the man who well deserves your help. Thrice, O ye Aśvins, bring us what shall make us glad; thrice send us store of food as nevermore to fail.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thrice, O ye Aśvins, bring to us abundant wealth: thrice in the Gods’ assembly, thrice assist our thoughts. Thrice, grant ye us prosperity, thrice grant us fame; for the Sun's daughter hath mounted your three-wheeled car.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thrice, Aśvins, grant to us the heavenly medicines, thrice those of earth and thrice those that the waters hold, Favour and health and strength bestow upon my son; triple protection, Lords of Splendour, grant to him.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thrice are ye to be worshipped day by day by us: thrice, O ye Aśvins, ye travel around the earth. Car-borne from far away, O ye Nāsatyas, come, like vital air to bodies, come ye to the three.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thrice, O ye Aśvins, with the Seven Mother Streams; three are the jars, the triple offering is prepared. Three are the worlds, and moving on above the sky ye guard the firm-set vault of heaven through days and nights.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Where are the three wheels of your triple chariot, where are the three seats thereto firmly fastened? When will ye yoke the mighty ass that draws it, to bring you to our sacrifice. Nāsatyas?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Nāsatyas, come: the sacred gift is offered up; drink the sweet juice with lips that know the sweetness well. Savitar sends, before the dawn of day, your car, fraught with oil, various-coloured, to our sacrifice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come, O Nāsatyas, with the thrice-eleven Gods; come, O ye Aśvins, to the drinking of the meath. Make long our days of life, and wipe out all our sins: ward off our enemies; be with us evermore.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Borne in your triple car, O Aśvins, bring us present prosperity with noble offspring. I cry to you who hear me for protection be ye our helpers where men win the booty. Next: HYMN XXXV. Savitar.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: AGNI I first invoke for our prosperity; I call on Mitra, Varuṇa, to aid us here. I call on Night who gives rest to all moving life; I call on Savitar the God to lend us help.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Throughout the dusky firmament advancing, laying to rest the immortal and the mortal, Borne in his golden chariot he cometh, Savitar, God who looks on every creature.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The God moves by the upward path, the downward; with two bright Bays, adorable, he journeys. Savitar comes, the God from the far distance, and chases from us all distress and sorrow.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: His chariot decked with pearl, of various colours, lofty, with golden pole, the God hath mounted, The many-rayed One, Savitar the holy, bound, bearing power and might, for darksome regions.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Drawing the gold-yoked car his Bays, white-footed, have manifested light to all the peoples. Held in the lap of Savitar, divine One, all men, all beings have their place for ever.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Three heavens there are; two Savitar's, adjacent: in Yama's world is one, the home of heroes, As on a linch-pin, firm, rest things immortal: he who hath known it let him here declare it.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He, strong of wing, hath lightened up the regions, deep-quivering Asura, the gentle Leader. Where now is Sūrya, where is one to tell us to what celestial sphere his ray hath wandered?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The earth's eight points his brightness hath illumined, three desert regions and the Seven Rivers. God Savitar the gold-eyed hath come hither, giving choice treasures unto him who worships.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The golden-handed Savitar, far-seeing, goes on his way between the earth and heaven, Drives away sickness, bids the Sun approach us, and spreads the bright sky through the darksome region.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May he, gold-handed Asura, kind Leader, come hither to us with his help and favour. Driving off Rākṣasas and Yātudhānas, the God is present, praised in hymns at evening.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Savitar, thine ancient dustless pathways are well established in the air's mid-region: O God, come by those paths so fair to travel, preserve thou us from harm this day, and bless us. Next: HYMN XXXVI. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: WITH words sent forth in holy hymns, Agni we supplicate, the Lord Of many families who duly serve the Gods, yea, him whom others also praise.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Men have won Agni, him who makes their strength abound: we, with oblations, worship thee. Our gracious-minded Helper in our deeds of might, be thou, O Excellent, this day.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thee for our messenger we choose, thee, the Omniscient, for our Priest. The flames of thee the mighty are spread wide around: thy splendour reaches to the sky.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Gods enkindle thee their ancient messenger,—Varuṇa, Mitra, Aryaman. That mortal man, O Agni, gains through thee all wealth, who hath poured offerings unto thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou, Agni, art a cheering Priest, Lord of the House, men's messenger: All constant high decrees established by the Gods, gathered together, meet in thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: In thee, the auspicious One, O Agni, youthfullest, each sacred gift is offered up: This day, and after, gracious, worship thou our Gods, that we may have heroic sons.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To him in his own splendour bright draw near in worship the devout. Men kindle Agni with their sacrificial gifts, victorious o’er the enemies.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Vṛtra they smote and slew, and made the earth and heaven and firmament a wide abode. The glorious Bull, invoked, hath stood at Kaṇva's side: loud neighed the Steed in frays for kine.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Seat thee, for thou art mighty; shine, best entertainer of the Gods. Worthy of sacred food, praised Agni! loose the smoke, ruddy and beautiful to see.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Bearer of offerings, whom, best sacrificing Priest, the Gods for Manu's sake ordained; Whom Kaṇva, whom Medhyātithi made the source of wealth, and Vṛṣan and Upastuta.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Him, Agni, whom Medhyātithi, whom Kaṇva kindled for his rite, Him these our songs of praise, him, Agni, we extol: his powers shine out preeminent.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Make our wealth perfect thou, O Agni, Lord divine: for thou hast kinship with the Gods. Thou rulest as a King o’er widely-famous strength: be good to us, for thou art great.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Stand up erect to lend us aid, stand up like Savitar the God: Erect as strength-bestower we call aloud, with unguents and with priests, on thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Erect, preserve us from sore trouble; with thy flame burn thou each ravening demon dead. Raise thou us up that we may walk and live: so thou shalt find our worship mid the Gods.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Preserve us, Agni, from the fiend, preserve us from malicious wrong. Save us from him who fain would injure us or slay, Most Youthful, thou with lofty light.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Smite down as with a club, thou who hast fire for teeth, smite thou the wicked, right and left. Let not the man who plots against us in the night, nor any foe prevail o’er us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni hath given heroic might to Kaṇva, and felicity: Agni hath helped our friends, hath helped Medhyātithi, hath helped Upastuta to win.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We call on Ugradeva, Yadu, Turvaśa, by means of Agni, from afar; Agni, bring Navavāstva and Bṛhadratha, Turvīti, to subdue the foe.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Manu hath stablished thee a light, Agni, for all the race of men: Sprung from the Law, oil-fed, for Kaṇva hast thou blazed, thou whom the people reverence.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The flames of Agni full of splendour and of might are fearful, not to be approached. Consume for ever all demons and sorcerers, consume thou each devouring fiend. Next: HYMN XXXVII. Maruts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: SING forth, O Kaṇvas, to your band of Maruts unassailable, Sporting, resplendent on their car

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: They who, self-luminous, were born together, with the spotted deer, Spears, swords, and glittering ornaments.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: One hears, as though ’twere close at hand, the cracking of the whips they hold They gather glory on their way.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Now sing ye forth the God-given hymn to your exultant Marut host, The fiercely-vigorous, the strong.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Praise ye the Bull among the cows; for ’tis the Maruts’ sportive band: It strengthened as it drank the rain.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Who is your mightiest, Heroes, when, O shakers of the earth and heaven, Ye shake them like a garment's hem?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: At your approach man holds him down before the fury of your wrath: The rugged-jointed mountain yields.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: They at whose racings forth the earth, like an age-weakened lord of men, Trembles in terror on their ways.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
