text: Strong is their birth: vigour have they to issue from their Mother; strength, Yea, even twice enough, is theirs.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: And these, the Sons, the Singers, in their racings have enlarged the bounds, So that the kine must walk knee-deep.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Before them, on the ways they go, they drop this offspring of the cloud, Long, broad, and inexhaustible.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Maruts, as your strength is great, so have ye cast men down on earth, So have ye made the mountains fall.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The while the Maruts pass along, they talk together on the way: Doth any hear them as they speak?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come quick with swift steeds, for ye have worshippers among Kaṇva's sons May you rejoice among them well.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: All is prepared for your delight. We are their servants evermore, To live as long as life may last. Next: HYMN XXXVIII. Maruts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: WHAT now? When will ye take us by both hands, as a dear sire his son, Gods, for whom sacred grass is clipped?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Now whither? To what goal of yours go ye in heaven, and not on earth? Where do your cows disport themselves?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Where are your newest favours shown? Where, Maruts, your prosperity? Where all your high felicities?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: If, O ye Maruts, ye the Sons whom Pṛśni bore, were mortal, and Immortal he who sings your praise.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Then never were your praiser loathed like a wild beast in pasture-land, Nor should he go on Yama's path.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Let not destructive plague on plague hard to be conquered, strike its down: Let each, with drought, depart from us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Truly, they the fierce and mighty Sons of Rudra send their windless Rain e’en on the desert places.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Like a cow the lightning lows and follows, motherlike, her youngling, When their rain-flood hath been loosened.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When they inundate the earth they spread forth darkness e’en in day time, With the water-laden rain-cloud.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Maruts, at your voice's sound this earthly habitation shakes, And each man reels who dwells therein.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Maruts, with your strong-hoofed steeds, unhindered in their courses, haste Along the bright embanked streams.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Firm be the fellies of your wheels, steady your horses and your cars, And may your reins be fashioned well.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Invite thou hither with this song, for praise, Agni the Lord of Prayer, Him who is fair as Mitra is.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Form in thy mouth the hymn of praise expand thee like, a rainy cloud Sing forth the measured eulogy.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Sing glory to the Marut host, praiseworthy, tuneful, vigorous: Here let the Strong Ones dwell with us. Next: HYMN XXXIX Maruts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: WHEN thus, like flame, from far away, Maruts, ye cast your measure forth, To whom go Ye, to whom, O shakers of the earth, moved by whose wisdom, whose design?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Strong let your weapons be to drive away your foes, firm for resistance let them be. Yea, passing glorious must be your warrior might, not as a guileful mortal's strength.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When what is strong ye overthrow, and whirl about each ponderous thing, Heroes, your course is through the forest trees of earth, and through the fissures of the rocks.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Consumers of your foes, no enemy of yours is found in heaven or on the earth: Ye Rudras, may the strength, held in this bond, be yours, to bid defiance even now.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: They make the mountains rock and reel, they rend the forest-kings apart. Onward, ye Maruts, drive, like creatures drunk with wine, ye, Gods with all your company.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ye to your chariot have yoked the spotted deer: a red deer, as a leader, draws. Even the Earth herself listened as ye came near, and men were sorely terrified.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Rudras, quickly we desire your succour for this work of ours. Come to us with your aid as in the days of old, so now for frightened Kaṇva's sake.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Should any monstrous foe, O Maruts, sent by you or sent by mortals threaten us, Tear ye him from us with your power and with your might, and with the succours that are yours.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For ye, the worshipful and wise, have guarded Kaṇva perfectly. O Maruts, come to us with full protecting help, as lightning flashes seek the rain.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whole strength have ye, O Bounteous Ones; perfect, earth-shakers, is your might. Maruts, against the poet's wrathful enemy send ye an enemy like a dart. Next: HYMN XL. Brahmaṇaspati

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O BRAHMAṆASPATI, stand up: God-serving men we pray to thee. May they who give good gifts, the Maruts, come to us. Indra, most swift, be thou with them.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Son of Strength, each mortal calls to thee for aid when spoil of battle waits for him. O Maruts, may this man who loves you well obtain wealth of good steeds and hero might.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May Brahmaṇaspati draw nigh, may Sūnṛtā the Goddess come, And Gods bring to this rite which gives the five-fold gift the Hero, lover of mankind.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He who bestows a noble guerdon on the priest wins fame that never shall decay. For him we offer sacred hero-giving food, peerless and conquering easily.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Now Brahmaṇaspati speaks forth aloud the solemn hymn of praise, Wherein Indra and Varuṇa, Mitra, Aryaman, the Gods, have made their dwelling place.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May we in holy synods, Gods! recite that hymn, peerless, that brings felicity. If you, O Heroes, graciously accept this word, may it obtain all bliss from you.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Who shall approach the pious? who the man whose sacred grass is trimmed? The offerer with his folk advances more and more: he fills his house with precious things.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He amplifies his lordly might, with kings he slays: e’en mid alarms he dwells secure In great or lesser fight none checks him, none subdues,—the wielder of the thunderbolt. Next: HYMN XLI. Varuṇa, Mitra, Aryaman.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: NE’ER is he injured whom the Gods Varuṇa, Mitra, Aryaman, The excellently wise, protect.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He prospers ever, free from scathe, whom they, as with full hands, enrich, Whom they preserve from every foe.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Kings drive far away from him his troubles and his enemies, And lead him safely o’er distress.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thornless, Ādityas, is the path, easy for him who seeks the Law: With him is naught to anger you.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: What sacrifice, Ādityas, ye Heroes guide by the path direct,— May that come nigh unto your thought.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: That mortal, ever unsubdued, gains wealth and every precious thing, And children also of his own.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: How, my friends, shall we prepare Aryaman's and Mitra's laud, Glorious food of Varuṇa?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I point not out to you a man who strikes the pious, or reviles: Only with hymns I call you nigh.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Let him not love to speak ill words: but fear the One who holds all four Within his hand, until they fall. Next: HYMN XLII. Pūṣan.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: SHORTEN our ways, O Pūṣan, move aside obstruction in the path: Go close before us, cloud-born God.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Drive, Pūṣan, from our road the wolf, the wicked inauspicious wolf, Who lies in wait to injure us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Who lurks about the path we take, the robber with a guileful heart: Far from the road chase him away.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Tread with thy foot and trample out the firebrand of the wicked one, The double-tongued, whoe’er he be.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Wise Pūṣan, Wonder-Worker, we claim of thee now the aid wherewith Thou furtheredst our sires of old.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So, Lord of all prosperity, best wielder of the golden sword, Make riches easy to be won.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Past all pursuers lead us, make pleasant our path and fair to tread: O Pūṣan, find thou power for this.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Lead us to meadows rich in grass: send on our way no early heat: O Pūṣan, find thou power for this.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Be gracious to us, fill us full, give, feed us, and invigorate: O Pūṣan, find thou power for this.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: No blame have we for Pūṣan; him we magnify with songs of praise: We seek the Mighty One for wealth. Next: HYMN XLIII. Rudra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: WHAT shall we sing to Rudra, strong, most bounteous, excellently wise, That shall be dearest to his heart?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: That Aditi may grant the grace of Rudra to our folk, our kine, Our cattle and our progeny;

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: That Mitra and that Varuṇa, that Rudra may remember us, Yea, all the Gods with one accord.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To Rudra Lord of sacrifice, of hymns and balmy medicines, We pray for joy and health and strength.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He shines in splendour like the Sun, refulgent as bright gold is he, The good, the best among the Gods.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May he grant health into our steeds, wellbeing to our rams and ewes, To men, to women, and to kine.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Soma, set thou upon us the glory of a hundred men, The great renown of mighty chiefs.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Let not malignities, nor those who trouble Soma, hinder us. Indu, give us a share of strength.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Soma! head, central point, love these; Soma! know these as serving thee, Children of thee Immortal, at the highest place of holy law. Next: HYMN XLIV. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: IMMORTAL Jātavedas, thou many-hued fulgent gift of Dawn, Agni, this day to him who pays oblations bring the Gods who waken with the morn.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For thou art offering-bearer and loved messenger, the charioteer of sacrifice: Accordant with the Aśvins and with Dawn grant us heroic strength and lofty fame.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As messenger we choose to-day Agni the good whom many love, Smoke-bannered spreader of the light, at break of day glory of sacrificial rites.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Him noblest and most youthful, richly worshipped guest, dear to the men who offer gifts, Him, Agni Jātavedas, I beseech at dawn that he may bring the Gods to us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thee, Agni, will I glorify, deathless nourisher of the world, Immortal, offering-bearer, meet for sacred food, preserver, best at sacrifice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Tell good things to thy praiser, O most youthful God, as richly worshipped, honey-tongued, And, granting to Praskaṇva lengthened days of life, show honour to the Heavenly Host.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For the men, Agni, kindle thee as all possessor and as Priest; So Agni, much-invoked, bring hither with all speed the Gods, the excellently wise,

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: At dawn of day, at night, Uṣas and Savitar, the Aśvins, Bhaga, Agni's self: Skilled in fair rites, with Soma poured, the Kaṇvas light thee, the oblation-wafting God.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For, Agni, Lord of sacrifice and messenger of men art thou: Bring thou the Gods who wake at dawn who see the light, this day to drink the Soma juice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou shonest forth, O Agni, after former dawns, all visible, O rich in light. Thou art our help in battle-strife, the Friend of man, the great high priest in sacrifice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Like Manu, we will stablish thee, Agni, performer of the rite, Invoker, ministering Priest, exceeding wise, the swift immortal messenger.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When as the Gods’ High Priest, by many loved, thou dost their mission as their nearest Friend, Then, like the far-resounding billows of the flood, thy flames, O Agni, roar aloud.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Hear, Agni, who hast ears to hear, with all thy train of escort Gods; Let Mitra, Aryaman, seeking betimes our rite, seat them upon the sacred grass.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Let those who strengthen Law, who bountifully give, the life-tongued Maruts, hear our praise. May Law-supporting Varuṇa with the Aśvins twain and Uṣas, drink the Soma juice. Next: HYMN XLV. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: WORSHIP the Vasus, Agni! here, the Rudras, the Ādityas, all Who spring from Manu, those who know fair rites, who pour their blessings down.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni, the Gods who understand give ear unto the worshipper: Lord of Red Steeds, who lovest song, bring thou those Three-and-Thirty Gods.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Jātavedas, great in act, hearken thou to Praskaṇva's call, As Priyamedha erst was heard, Atri, Virūpa, Aṅgiras.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The sons of Priyamedha skilled in lofty praise have called for help On Agni who with fulgent flame is Ruler of all holy rites.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Hear thou, invoked with holy oil, bountiful giver of rewards, These eulogies, whereby the sons of Kaṇva call thee to their aid.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Agni, loved by many, thou of fame most wondrous, in their homes Men call on thee whose hair is flame, to be the bearer of their gifts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thee, Agni, best to find out wealth, most widely famous, quick to hear, Singers have stablished in their rites Herald and ministering Priest.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Singers with Soma pressed have made thee, Agni, hasten to the feast, Great light to mortal worshipper, what time they bring the sacred gift.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Good, bounteous, Son of Strength, this day seat here on sacred grass the Gods Who come at early morn, the host of heaven, to drink the Soma juice

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Bring with joint invocations thou, O Agni, the celestial host: Here stands the Soma, bounteous Gods drink this expressed ere yesterday. Next: HYMN XLVI. Aśvins.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Now Morning with her earliest light shines forth, dear Daughter of the Sky: High, Aśvins, I extol your praise,

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Sons of the Sea, mighty to save discoverers of riches, ye Gods with deep thought who find out wealth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Your giant coursers hasten on over the region all in flames, When your car flies with winged steeds.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He, liberal, lover of the flood, Lord of the House, the vigilant, Chiefs! with oblations feeds you full.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ye have regard unto our hymns, Nāsatyas, thinking of our words: Drink boldly of the Soma juice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Vouchsafe to us, O Aśvin Pair, such strength as, with attendant light, May through the darkness carry us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come in the ship of these our hymns to bear you to the hither shore O Aśvins, harness ye the car.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The heaven's wide vessel is your own on the flood's shore your chariot waits Drops, with the hymn, have been prepared.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Kaṇvas, the drops are in the heaven; the wealth is at the waters' place: Where will ye manifest your form?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Light came to lighten up the branch, the Sun appeared as it were gold: And with its tongue shone forth the dark.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The path of sacrifice was made to travel to the farther goal: The road of heaven was manifest.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The singer of their praise awaits whatever grace the Aśvins give, who save when Soma gladdens them.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ye dwellers with Vivasvān come, auspicious, as to Manu erst; come to the Soma and our praise.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O circumambient Aśvins, Dawn follows the brightness of your way: Approve with beams our solemn rites.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Drink ye of our libations, grant protection, O ye Aśvins Twain, With aids which none may interrupt. Next: HYMN XLVII. Aśvins.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: AŚVINS, for you who strengthen Law this sweetest Soma hath been shed. Drink this expressed ere yesterday and give riches to him who offers it.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come, O ye Aśvins, mounted on your triple car three-seated, beautiful of form To you at sacrifice the Kaṇvas send the prayer: graciously listen to their call.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Aśvins, ye who strengthen Law, drink ye this sweetest Soma juice. Borne on your wealth-fraught car come ye this day to him who offers, ye of wondrous deeds.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Omniscient Aśvins, on the thrice-heaped grass bedew with the sweet juice the sacrifice. The sons of Kaṇva, striving heavenward, call on you with draughts of Soma juice out-poured.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Aśvins, with those aids wherewith ye guarded Kaṇva carefully, Keep us, O Lords of Splendour: drink the Soma juice, ye strengtheners of holy law.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Mighty Ones, ye gave Sudās abundant food, brought on your treasure-laden car; So now vouchsafe to us the wealth which many crave, either from heaven or from the sea.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Nāsatyas, whether ye be far away or close to Turvaśa, Borne on your lightly-rolling chariot come to us, together with the sunbeams come.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So let your coursers, ornaments of sacrifice, bring you to our libations here. Bestowing food on him who acts and gives aright, sit, Chiefs, upon the sacred grass.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come, O Nāsatyas, on your car decked with a sunbright canopy, Whereon ye ever bring wealth to the worshipper, to drink the Soma's pleasant juice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With lauds and songs of praise we call them down to us, that they, most rich, may succour us; For ye have ever in the Kaṇvas' well-loved house, O Aśvins, drunk the Soma juice. Next: HYMN XLVIII. Dawn.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: DAWN on us with prosperity, O Uṣas, Daughter of the Sky, Dawn with great glory, Goddess, Lady of the Light, dawn thou with riches, Bounteous One.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: They, bringing steeds and kine, boon-givers of all wealth, have oft sped forth to lighten us. O Uṣas, waken up for me the sounds of joy: send us the riches of the great.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Uṣas hath dawned, and now shall dawn, the Goddess, driver forth of cars Which, as she cometh nigh, have fixed their thought on her, like glory-seekers on the flood.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Here Kaṇva, chief of Kaṇva's race, sings forth aloud the glories of the heroes’ names,— The. princes who, O Uṣas, as thou comest near, direct their thoughts to liberal gifts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Like a good matron Uṣas comes carefully tending everything: Rousing all life she stirs all creatures that have feet, and makes the birds of air fly up.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: She sends the busy forth, each man to his pursuit: delay she knows not as she springs. O rich in opulence, after thy dawning birds that have flown forth no longer rest.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This Dawn hath yoked her steeds afar, beyond the rising of the Sun: Borne on a hundred chariots she, auspicious Dawn, advances on her way to Men.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To meet her glance all living creatures bend them down: Excellent One, she makes the light. Uṣas, the Daughter of the Sky, the opulent, shines foes and enmities away.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Shine on us with thy radiant light, O Uṣas, Daughter of the Sky, Bringing to us great store of high felicity, and beaming on our solemn rites.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For in thee is each living creature's breath and life, when, Excellent! thou dawnest forth. Borne on thy lofty car, O Lady of the Light, hear, thou of wondrous wealth, our call.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Uṣas, win thyself the strength which among men is wonderful. Bring thou thereby the pious unto holy rites, those who as priests sing praise to thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Bring from the firmament, O Uṣas, all the Gods, that they may drink our Soma juice, And, being what thou art, vouchsafe us kine and steeds, strength meet for praise and hero might.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May Uṣas whose auspicious rays are seen resplendent round about, Grant us great riches, fair in form, of all good things, wealth which light labour may attain.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Mighty One, whom the Ṛṣis of old time invoked for their protection and their help, O Uṣas, graciously answer our songs of praise with bounty and with brilliant light.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Uṣas, as thou with light to day hast opened the twin doors of heaven, So grant thou us a dwelling wide and free from foes. O Goddess, give us food with kine.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Bring us to wealth abundant, sent in every shape, to plentiful refreshing food, To all-subduing splendour, Uṣas, Mighty One, to strength, thou rich in spoil and wealth. Next: HYMN XLIX. Dawn.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: E'EN from above the sky's bright realm come, Uṣas, by auspicious ways: Let red steeds bear thee to the house of him who pours the Soma, juice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The chariot which thou mountest, fair of shape, O Uṣas light to move,— Therewith, O Daughter of the Sky, aid men of noble fame today.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Bright Uṣas, when thy times return, all quadrupeds and bipeds stir, And round about flock winged birds from all the boundaries of heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou dawning with thy beams of light illumest all the radiant realm. Thee, as thou art, the Kaṇvas, fain for wealth, have called with sacred songs. Next: HYMN L. Sūrya.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: HIS bright rays bear him up aloft, the God who knoweth all that lives, Sūrya, that all may look on him.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The constellations pass away, like thieves, together with their beams, Before the all-beholding Sun.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: His herald rays are seen afar refulgent o’er the world of men, Like flames of fire that burn and blaze.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Swift and all beautiful art thou, O Sūrya, maker of the light, Illuming all the radiant realm.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou goest to the hosts of Gods, thou comest hither to mankind, Hither all light to be beheld.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With that same eye of thine wherewith thou lookest brilliant Varuṇa, Upon the busy race of men,

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Traversing sky and wide mid-air, thou metest with thy beams our days, Sun, seeing all things that have birth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Seven Bay Steeds harnessed to thy car bear thee, O thou farseeing One, God, Sūrya, with the radiant hair.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Sūrya hath yoked the pure bright Seven, the daughters of the car; with these, His own dear team, he goeth forth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Looking upon the loftier light above the darkness we have come To Sūrya, God among the Gods, the light that is most excellent.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Rising this day, O rich in friends, ascending to the loftier heaven, Sūrya remove my heart's disease, take from me this my yellow hue.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To parrots and to starlings let us give away my yellowness, Or this my yellowness let us transfer to Haritāla trees.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With all his conquering vigour this Āditya hath gone up on high, Giving my foe into mine hand: let me not be my foeman's prey. Next: HYMN LI. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: MAKE glad with songs that Ram whom many men invoke, worthy of songs of praise, Indra, the sea of wealth; Whose gracious deeds for men spread like the heavens abroad: sing praise to him the Sage, most liberal for our good.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As aids the skilful Ṛbhus yearned to Indra strong to save, who fills mid-air, encompassed round with might, Rushing in rapture; and o’er Śatakratu came the gladdening shout that urged him on to victory.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou hast disclosed the kine's stall for the Aṅgirases, and made a way for Atri by a hundred doors. On Vimada thou hast bestowed both food and wealth, making thy bolt dance in the sacrificer's fight.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou hast unclosed the prisons of the waters; thou hast in the mountain seized the treasure rich in gifts. When thou hadst slain with might the dragon Vṛtra, thou, Indra, didst raise the Sun in heaven for all to see.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With wondrous might thou blewest enchanter fiends away, with powers celestial those who called on thee in jest. Thou, hero-hearted, hast broken down Pipru's forts, and helped Ṛjiśvan when the Dasyus were struck dead.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou savedst Kutsa when Śuṣṇa was smitten down; to Atithigva gavest Śambara for a prey. E’en mighty Arbuda thou troddest under foot: thou from of old wast born to strike the Dasyus dead.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: All power and might is closely gathered up in thee; thy bounteous spirit joys in drinking Soma juice. Known is the thunderbolt that lies within thine arms: rend off therewith all manly prowess of our foe.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Discern thou well Āryas and Dasyus; punishing the lawless give them up to him whose grass is strewn. Be thou the sacrificer's strong encourager all these thy deeds are my delight at festivals.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra gives up the lawless to the pious man, destroying by the Strong Ones those who have no strength. Vamra when glorified destroyed the gathered piles of the still waxing great one who would reach the heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The might which Uśanā hath formed for thee with might rends in its greatness and with strength both worlds apart. O Hero-souled, the steeds of Vāta, yoked by thought, have carried thee to fame while thou art filled with power.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When Indra hath rejoiced with Kāvya Uśanā, he mounts his steeds who swerve wider and wider yet. The Strong hath loosed his bolt with the swift rush of rain, and he hath rent in pieces Śuṣṇa's firm-built forts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou mountest on thy car amid strong Soma draughts: Śāryāta brought thee those in which thou hast delight. Indra, when thou art pleased with men whose Soma flows thou risest to unchallenged glory in the sky.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To old Kakṣīvān, Soma-presser, skilled in song, O Indra, thou didst give the youthful Vṛcayā. Thou, very wise, wast Menā, Vrsanśva's child: those deeds of thine must all be told at Soma feasts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The good man's refuge in his need is Indra, firm as a doorpost, praised among the Pajras. Indra alone is Lord of wealth, the Giver, lover of riches, chariots, kine, and horses.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To him the Mighty One, the self-resplendent, verily strong and great, this praise is uttered. May we and all the heroes, with the princes, be, in this fray, O Indra, in thy keeping. Next: HYMN LII. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I GLORIFY that Ram who finds the light of heaven, whose hundred nobly-natured ones go forth with him. With hymns may I turn hither Indra to mine aid,—the Car which like a strong steed hasteth to the call.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Like as a mountain on firm basis, unremoved, he, thousandfold protector, waxed in mighty strength, When Indra, joying in the draughts of Soma juice, forced the clouds, slaying Vṛtra stayer of their flow.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For he stays e’en the stayers, spread o’er laden cloud, rooted in light, strengthened in rapture by the wise. Indra with thought, with skilled activity, I call, most liberal giver, for he sates him with the juice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whom those that flow in heaven on sacred grass, his own assistants, nobly-natured, fill full like the sea,— Beside that Indra when he smote down Vṛtra stood his helpers, straight in form, mighty, invincible.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To him, as in wild joy he fought with him who stayed the rain, his helpers sped like swift streams down a slope, When Indra, thunder-armed, made bold by Soma draughts, as Tṛta cleaveth Vala's fences, cleft him through.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Splendour encompassed thee, forth shone thy warrior might: the rain-obstructer lay in mid-air's lowest deep, What time, O Indra, thou didst cast thy thunder down upon the jaws of Vṛitra hard to be restrained.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The hymns which magnify thee, Indra, reach to thee even as water-brooks flow down and fill the lake. Tvaṣṭar gave yet more force to thine appropriate strength, and forged thy thunderbolt of overpowering might.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When, Indra, thou whose power is linked with thy Bay Steeds hadst smitten Vṛtra, causing floods to flow for man, Thou heldst in thine arms the metal thunderbolt, and settest in the heaven the Sun for all to see.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: In fear they raised the lofty self-resplendent hymn, praise giving and effectual, leading up to heaven, When Indra's helpers fighting for the good of men, the Maruts, faithful to mankind, joyed in the light.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Then Heaven himself, the mighty, at that Dragon's roar reeled back in terror when, Indra, thy thunderbolt In the wild joy of Soma had struck off with might the head of Vṛtra, tyrant of the earth and heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indra, were this earth extended forth tenfold, and men who dwell therein multiplied day by day, Still here thy conquering might, Maghavan, would be famed: it hath waxed vast as heaven in majesty and power.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou, bold of heart, in thine own native might, for help, upon the limit of this mid-air and of heaven, Hast made the earth to be the pattern of thy strength: embracing flood and light thou reachest to the sky.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou art the counterpart of earth, the Master of lofty heaven with all its mighty Heroes: Thou hast filled all the region with thy greatness: yea, of a truth there is none other like thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whose amplitude the heaven and earth have not attained, whose bounds the waters of mid-air have never reached,— Not, when in joy he fights the stayer of the rain: thou, and none else, hast made all things in order due.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Maruts sang thy praise in this encounter, and in thee all the Deities delighted, What time thou, Indra, with thy spiky weapon, thy deadly bolt, smotest the face of Vṛtra. Next: HYMN LIII. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: WE will present fair praise unto the Mighty One, our hymns to Indra in Vivasvān's dwelling-place; For he hath ne’er found wealth in those who seem to sleep: those who give wealth to men accept no paltry praise.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Giver of horses, Indra, giver, thou, of kine, giver of barley, thou art Lord and guard of wealth: Man's helper from of old, not disappointing hope, Friend of our friends, to thee as such we sing this praise.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra, most splendid, powerful, rich in mighty deeds, this treasure spread around is known to be thine own. Gather therefrom, O Conqueror, and bring to us: fail not the hope of him who loves and sings to thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Well pleased with these bright flames and with these Soma drops, take thou away our poverty with seeds and kine. With Indra scattering the Dasyu through these drops, freed from their hate may we obtain abundant food.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Let us obtain, O Indra, plenteous wealth and food, with strength exceeding glorious, shining to the sky: May we obtain the Goddess Providence, the strength of heroes, special source of cattle, rich in steeds.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: These our libations strength-inspiring, Soma draughts, gladdened thee in the fight with Vṛtra, Hero Lord, What time thou slewest for the singer with trimmed grass ten thousand Vṛtras, thou resistless in thy might.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou goest on from fight to fight intrepidly, destroying castle after castle here with strength. Thou, Indra, with thy friend who makes the foe bow down, slewest from far away the guileful Namuci.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou hast struck down in death Karañja, Parṇaya, in Atithigva's very glorious going forth. Unyielding, when Ṛjiśvan compassed them with siege, thou hast destroyed the hundred forts of Vaṅgṛida.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With all-outstripping chariot-wheel, O Indra, thou far-famed, hast overthrown the twice ten Kings of men, With sixty thousand nine-and-ninety followers, who came in arms to fight with friendless Suśravas.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou hast protected Suśravas with succour, and Tūrvayāṇa with thine aid, O Indra. Thou madest Kutsa, Atithigva, Āyu, subject unto this King, the young, the mighty.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May we protected by the Gods hereafter remain thy very prosperous friends, O Indra. Thee we extol, enjoying through thy favour life long and joyful and with store of heroes. Next: HYMN LIV. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: URGE us not, Maghavan, to this distressful fight, for none may comprehend the limit of thy strength. Thou with fierce shout hast made the woods and rivers roar: did not men run in crowds together in their fear?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Sing hymns of praise to Śakra, Lord of power and might; laud thou and magnify Indra who heareth thee, Who with his daring might, a Bull exceeding strong in strength, maketh him master of the heaven and earth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Sing forth to lofty Dyaus a strength-bestowing song, the Bold, whose resolute mind hath independent sway. High glory hath the Asura, compact of strength, drawn on by two Bay Steeds: a Bull, a Car is he.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The ridges of the lofty heaven thou madest shake; thou, daring, of thyself smotest through Śambara, When bold with gladdening juice, thou warredst with thy bolt, sharp and two-edged, against the banded sorcerers.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When with a roar that fills the woods, thou forcest down on wind's head the stores which Śuṣṇa kept confined, Who shall have power to stay thee firm and eager-souled from doing still this day what thou of old hast done?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou helpest Narya, Turvaśa, and Yadu, and Vayya's son Turvīti, Śatakratu! Thou helpest horse and car in final battle thou breakest down the nine-and-ninety castles.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: A hero-lord is he, King of a mighty folk, who offers free oblations and promotes the Law, Who with a bounteous guerdon welcomes hymns of praise: for him flows down the abundant stream below the sky.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: His power is matchless, matchless is his wisdom; chief, through their work, be some who drink the Soma, Those, Indra, who increase the lordly power, the firm heroic strength of thee the Giver.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Therefore for thee are these abundant beakers Indra's drink, stone-pressed juices held in ladles. Quaff them and satisfy therewith thy longing; then fix thy mind upon bestowing treasure.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: There darkness stood, the vault that stayed the waters’ flow: in Vṛtra's hollow side the rain-cloud lay concealed. But Indra smote the rivers which the obstructer stayed, flood following after flood, down steep declivities.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So give us, Indra, bliss-increasing glory give us great sway and strength that conquers people. Preserve our wealthy patrons, save our princes; vouchsafe us wealth and food with noble offspring. Next: HYMN LV. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: THOUGH e’en this heaven's wide space and earth have spread them out, nor heaven nor earth may be in greatness Indra's match. Awful and very mighty, causing woe to men, he whets his thunderbolt for sharpness, as a bull.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Like as the watery ocean, so doth he receive the rivers spread on all sides in their ample width. He bears him like a bull to drink of Soma juice, and will, as Warrior from of old, be praised for might.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou swayest, Indra, all kinds of great manly power, so as to bend, as’t were, even that famed mountain down. Foremost among the Gods is he through hero might, set in the van, the Strong One, for each arduous deed.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He only in the wood is praised by worshippers, when he shows forth to men his own fair Indra-power. A friendly Bull is he, a Bull to be desired when Maghavan auspiciously sends forth his voice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Yet verily the Warrior in his vigorous strength stirreth up with his might great battles for mankind; And men have faith in Indra, the resplendent One, what time he hurleth down his bolt, his dart of death.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Though, fain for glory, and with strength increased on earth, he with great might destroys the dwellings made with art, He makes the lights of heaven shine forth secure, he bids, exceeding wise, the floods flow for his worshipper.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Drinker of Soma, let thy heart incline to give; bring thy Bays hitherward, O thou who hearest praise. Those charioteers of thine, best skilled to draw the rein, the rapid sunbeams, Indra, lead thee not astray.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou bearest in both hands treasure that never fails; the famed One in his body holds unvanquished might. O Indra, in thy members many powers abide, like wells surrounded by the ministering priests. Next: HYMN LVI. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: FOR this man's full libations held in ladles, he hath roused him, eager, as a horse to meet the mare. He stays his golden car, yoked with Bay Horses, swift, and drinks the Soma juice which strengthens for great deeds.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To him the guidance-following songs of praise flow full, as those who seek gain go in company to the flood. To him the Lord of power, the holy synod's might, as to a hill, with speed, ascend the loving ones.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Victorious, great is he; in manly battle shines, unstained with dust, his might, as shines a mountain peak; Wherewith the iron one, fierce e’en against the strong, in rapture, fettered wily Śushṇa fast in bonds.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When Strength the Goddess, made more strong for help by thee, waits upon Indra as the Sun attends the Dawn, Then. he who with his might unflinching kills the gloom stirs up the dust aloft, with joy and triumphing.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When thou with might, upon the framework of the heaven, didst fix, across, air's region firmly, unremoved, In the light-winning war, Indra, in rapturous joy, thou smotest Vṛtra dead and broughtest floods of rain.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou with thy might didst grasp, the holder-up of heaven, thou who art mighty also in the seats of earth. Thou, gladdened by the juice, hast set the waters free, and broken Vṛtra's stony fences through and through. Next: HYMN LVII. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To him most liberal, lofty Lord of lofty wealth, verily powerful and strong, I bring my hymn,— Whose checkless bounty, as of waters down a slope, is spread abroad for all that live, to give them strength.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Now all this world, for worship, shall come after thee—the offerer's libations like floods to the depth, When the well-loved one seems to rest upon the hill, the thunderbolt of Indra, shatterer wrought of gold.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To him the terrible, most meet for lofty praise, like bright Dawn, now bring gifts with reverence in this rite, Whose being, for renown, yea, Indra-power and light, have been created, like bay steeds, to move with speed.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thine, Indra, praised by many, excellently rich! are we who trusting in thy help draw near to thee. Lover of praise, none else but thou receives our laud: as earth loves all her creatures, love thou this our hymn.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Great is thy power, O Indra, we are thine. Fulfil, O Maghavan, the wish of this thy worshipper. After thee lofty heaven hath measured out its strength: to thee and to thy power this earth hath bowed itself.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou, who hast thunder for thy weapon, with thy bolt hast shattered into pieces this broad massive cloud. Thou hast sent down the obstructed floods that they may flow: thou hast, thine own for ever, all victorious might. Next: HYMN LVIII. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: NE’ER waxeth faint the Immortal, Son of Strength, since he, the Herald, hath become Vivasvān's messenger. On paths most excellent he measured out mid-air: he with oblation calls to service of the Gods.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Never decaying, seizing his appropriate food, rapidly, eagerly through the dry wood he spreads. His back, as he is sprinkled, glistens like a horse: loud hath he roared and shouted like the heights of heaven?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Set high in place o’er all that Vasus, Rudras do, immortal, Lord of riches, seated as High Priest; Hastening like a car to men, to those who live, the God without delay gives boons to be desired.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Urged by the wind be spreads through dry wood as he lists, armed with his tongues for sickles, with a mighty roar. Black is thy path, Agni, changeless, with glittering waves! when like a bull thou rushest eager to the trees.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With teeth of flame, wind-driven, through the wood he speeds, triumphant like a bull among the herd of cows, With bright strength roaming to the everlasting air: things fixed, things moving quake before him as he flies.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Bhṛgus established thee among mankind for men, like as a treasure, beauteous, easy to invoke; Thee, Agni, as a herald and choice-worthy guest, as an auspicious Friend to the Celestial Race.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni, the seven tongues' deftest Sacrificer, him whom the priests elect at solemn worship, The Herald, messenger of all the Vasus, I serve with dainty food, I ask for riches.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Grant, Son of Strength, thou rich in friends, a refuge without a flaw this day to us thy praisers. O Agni, Son of Strength, with forts of iron preserve thou from distress the man who lauds thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Be thou a refuge, Bright One, to the singer, a shelter, Bounteous Lord, to those who worship. Preserve the singer from distress, O Agni. May he, enriched with prayer, come soon and early. Next: HYMN LIX. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: THE other fires are, verily, thy branches; the Immortals all rejoice in thee, O Agni. Centre art thou, Vaiśvānara, of the people, sustaining men like a deep-founded pillar.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The forehead of the sky, earth's centre, Agni became the messenger of earth and heaven. Vaiśvānara, the Deities produced thee, a God, to be a light unto the Ārya.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As in the Sun firm rays are set for ever, treasures are in Vaiśvānara, in Agni. Of all the riches in the hills, the waters, the herbs, among mankind, thou art the Sovran.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As the great World-halves, so are their Son's praises; skilled, as a man, to act, is he the Herald. Vaiśvānara, celestial, truly mighty, most manly One, hath many a youthful consort.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Even the lofty heaven, O Jātavedas Vaiśvānara, hath not attained thy greatness. Thou art the King of lands where men are settled, thou hast brought comfort to the Gods in battle.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Now will I tell the greatness of the Hero whom Pūru's sons follow as Vṛtra's slayer: Agni Vaiśvānara struck down the Dasyu, cleave Śambara through and shattered down his fences.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Vaiśvānara, dwelling by his might with all men, far-shining, holy mid the Bharadvājas, Is lauded, excellent, with hundred praises by Purūṇītha, son of Śatavani. Next: HYMN LX. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As ’twere Some goodly treasure Mātariśvan brought, as a gift, the glorious Priest to Bhṛgu, Banner of sacrifice, the good Protector, child of two births, the swiftly moving envoy.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Both Gods and men obey this Ruler's order, Gods who are worshipped, men who yearn and worship. As Priest he takes his seat ere break of morning, House-Lord, adorable with men, Ordainer.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May our fair praise, heart-born, most recent, reach him whose tongue, e’en at his birth, is sweet as honey; Whom mortal priests, men, with their strong endeavour, supplied with dainty viands, have created.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Good to mankind, the yearning Purifier hath among men been placed as Priest choice-worthy. May Agni be our Friend, Lord of the Household, protector of the riches in the dwelling.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As such we Gotamas with hymns extol thee, O Agni, as the guardian Lord of riches, Decking thee like a horse, the swift prizewinner. May he, enriched with prayer, come soon and early. Next: HYMN LXI. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: EVEN to him, swift, strong and high. exalted, I bring my song of praise as dainty viands, My thought to him resistless, praise-deserving, prayers offered most especially to Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Praise, like oblation, I present, and utter aloud my song, my fair hymn to the Victor. For Indra, who is Lord of old, the singers have decked their lauds with heart and mind and spirit.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To him then with my lips mine adoration, winning heaven's light, most excellent, I offer, To magnify with songs of invocation and with fair hymns the Lord, most bounteous Giver.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Even for him I frame a laud, as fashions the wright a chariot for the man who needs it,— Praises to him who gladly hears our praises, a hymn well-formed, all-moving, to wise Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So with my tongue I deck, to please that Indra, my hymn, as ’twere a horse, through love of glory, To reverence the Hero, bounteous Giver, famed far and wide, destroyer of the castles.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Even for him hath Tvaṣṭar forged the thunder, most deftly wrought, celestial, for the battle, Wherewith he reached the vital parts of Vṛtra, striking-the vast, the mighty with the striker.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As soon as, at libations of his mother, great Viṣṇu had drunk up the draught, he plundered. The dainty cates, the cooked mess; but One stronger transfixed the wild boar, shooting through the mountain.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To him, to Indra, when he slew the Dragon, the Dames, too, Consorts of the Gods, wove praises. The mighty heaven and earth hath he encompassed: thy greatness heaven and earth, combined, exceed not.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Yea, of a truth, his magnitude surpasseth the magnitude of earth, mid-air, and heaven. Indra, approved by all men, self-resplendent, waxed in his home, loud-voiced and strong for battle.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Through his own strength Indra with bolt of thunder cut piece-meal Vṛtra, drier up of waters. He let the floods go free, like cows imprisoned, for glory, with a heart inclined to bounty.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The rivers played, through his impetuous splendour, since with his bolt he compassed them on all sides. Using his might and favouring him who worshipped, he made a ford, victorious, for Turvīti.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Vast, with thine ample power, with eager movement, against this Vṛtra cast thy bolt of thunder. Rend thou his joints, as of an ox, dissevered, with bolt oblique, that floods of rain may follow.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Sing with new lauds his exploits wrought aforetime, the deeds of him, yea, him who moveth swiftly, When, hurling forth his weapons in the battle, he with impetuous wrath lays low the foemen.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When he, yea, he, comes forth the firm. Set mountains and the whole heaven and earth, tremble for terror. May Nodhas, ever praising the protection of that dear Friend, gain quickly strength heroic.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Now unto him of these things hath been given what he who rules alone o’er much, electeth. Indra hath helped Etaśa, Soma-presser, contending in the race of steeds with Sūrya.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thus to thee, Indra, yoker of Bay Coursers, the Gotamas have brought their prayers to please thee. Bestow upon them thought, decked with all beauty. May he, enriched with prayer, come soon and early. Next: HYMN LXII. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: LIKE Aṅgiras a gladdening laud we ponder to him who loveth song, exceeding mighty. Let us sing glory to the far-famed Hero who must be praised with fair hymns by the singer.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Unto the great bring ye great adoration, a chant with praise to him exceeding mighty, Through whom our sires, Aṅgirases, singing praises and knowing well the places, found the cattle.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When Indra and the Aṅgirases desired it, Saramā found provision for her offspring. Bṛhaspati cleft the mountain, found the cattle: the heroes shouted with the kine in triumph.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Mid shout, loud shout, and roar, with the Navagvas, seven singers, hast thou, heavenly, rent the mountain; Thou hast, with speeders, with Daśagvas, Indra, Śakra, with thunder rent obstructive Vala.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Praised by Aṅgirases, thou, foe-destroyer, hast, with the Dawn, Sun, rays, dispelled the darkness. Thou Indra, hast spread out the earth's high ridges, and firmly fixed the region under heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This is the deed most worthy of all honour, the fairest marvel of the Wonder-Worker, That, nigh where heaven bends down, he made four rivers flow full with waves that carry down sweet water.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Unwearied, won with lauding hymns, he parted of old the ancient Pair, united ever. In highest sky like Bhaga, he the doer of marvels set both Dames and earth and heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Still born afresh, young Dames, each in her manner, unlike in hue, the Pair in alternation Round heaven and earth from ancient time have travelled, Night with her dark limbs, Dawn with limbs of splendour.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Rich in good actions, skilled in operation, the Son with might maintains his perfect friendship. Thou in the raw cows, black of hue or ruddy, storest the ripe milk glossy white in colour.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Their paths, of old connected, rest uninjured; they with great might preserve the immortal statutes. For many thousand holy works the Sisters wait on the haughty Lord like wives and matrons.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thoughts ancient, seeking wealth, with adoration, with newest lauds have sped to thee, O Mighty. As yearning wives cleave to their yearning husband, so cleave our hymns to thee, O Lord most potent.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Strong God, the riches which thy hands have holden from days of old have perished not nor wasted. Splendid art thou, O Indra, wise, unbending: strengthen us with might, O Lord of Power.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O mighty Indra, Gotama's son Nodhas hath fashioned this new prayer to thee Eternal, Sure leader, yoker of the Tawny Coursers. May he, enriched with prayer, come soon and early. Next: HYMN LXIII. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: THOU art the Mighty One; when born, O Indra, with power thou terrifiedst earth and heaven; When, in their fear of thee, all firm-set mountains and monstrous creatures shook like dust before thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When thy two wandering Bays thou drawest hither, thy praiser laid within thine arms the thunder, Wherewith, O Much-invoked, in will resistless, thou smitest foemen down and many a castle.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Faithful art thou, these thou defiest, Indra; thou art the Ṛbhus' Lord, heroic, victor. Thou, by his side, for young and glorious Kutsa, with steed and car in battle slewest Śuṣṇa,

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: That, as a friend, thou furtheredst, O Indra, when, Thunderer, strong in act, thou crushedst Vṛtra; When, Hero, thou, great-souled, with easy conquest didst rend the Dasyus in their distant dwelling.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This doest thou, and art not harmed, O Indra, e’en in the anger of the strongest mortal. Lay thou the race-course open for our horses: as with a club, slay, Thunder-armed! our foemen.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Hence men invoke thee, Indra, in the tumult of battle, in the light-bestowing conflict. This aid of thine, O Godlike One, was ever to be implored in deeds of might in combat.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Warring for Purukutsa thou, O Indra, Thunder-armed! breakest down the seven castles; Easily, for Sudās, like grass didst rend them, and out of need, King, broughtest gain to Pūru.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indra, God who movest round about us, feed us with varied food plenteous as water— Food wherewithal, O Hero, thou bestowest vigour itself to flow to us for ever.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Prayers have been made by Gotamas, O Indra, addressed to thee, with laud for thy Bay Horses. Bring us in noble shape abundant riches. May he, enriched with prayer, come soon and early. Next: HYMN LXIV. Maruts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: BRING for the manly host, wise and majestical, O Nodhas, for the Maruts bring thou a pure gift. I deck my songs as one deft-handed, wise in mind prepares the water that hath power in solemn rites.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: They spring to birth, the lofty Ones, the Bulls of Heaven, divine, the youths of Rudra, free from spot and stain; The purifiers, shining brightly even as suns, awful of form like giants, scattering rain-drops down.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Young Rudras, demon-slayers, never growing old, they have waxed, even as mountains, irresistible. They make all beings tremble with their mighty strength, even the very strongest, both of earth and heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With glittering ornaments they deck them forth for show; for beauty on their breasts they bind their chains of gold. The lances on their shoulders pound to pieces; they were born together, of themselves, the Men of Heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Loud roarers, giving strength, devourers of the foe, they make the winds, they make the lightnings with their powers. The restless shakers drain the udders of the sky, and ever wandering round fill the earth full with milk.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The bounteous Maruts with the fatness dropping milk fill full the waters which avail in solemn rites. They lead, as ’twere, the Strong Horse forth, that it may rain: they milk the thundering, the never-failing spring.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Mighty, with wondrous power and marvellously bright, selfstrong like mountains, ye glide swiftly on your way. Like the wild elephants ye eat the forests up when ye assume your strength among the bright red flames.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Exceeding wise they roar like lions mightily, they, all-possessing, are beauteous as antelopes; Stirring the darkness with lances and spotted deer, combined as priests, with serpents' fury through their might.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Heroes who march in companies, befriending man, with serpents' ire through strength, ye greet the earth and heaven. Upon the seats, O Maruts, of your chariots, upon the cars stands lightning visible as light.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Lords of all riches, dwelling in the home of wealth, endowed with mighty vigour, singers loud of voice, Heroes, of powers infinite, armed with strong men's rings, the archers, they have laid the arrow on their arms.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: They who with golden fellies make the rain increase drive forward the big clouds like wanderers on the way. Self-moving, brisk, unwearied, they o’erthrow the firm; the Maruts with bright lances make all things to reel.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The progeny of Rudra we invoke with prayer, the brisk, the bright, the worshipful, the active Ones To the strong band of Maruts cleave for happiness, the chasers of the sky, impetuous, vigorous.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Maruts, the man whom ye have guarded with your help, he verily in strength surpasseth all mankind. Spoil with his steeds he gaineth, treasure with his men; he winneth honourable strength and prospereth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Maruts, to the worshippers give glorious strength invincible in battle, brilliant, bringing wealth, Praiseworthy, known to all men. May we foster well, during a hundred winters, son and progeny.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Will ye then, O ye Maruts, grant us riches, durable, rich in men, defying onslaught. A hundred, thousandfold, ever increasing? May he, enriched with prayer, come soon and early. Next: HYMN LXV. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: ONE-MINDED, wise, they tracked thee like a thief lurking in dark cave with a stolen cow: Thee claiming worship, bearing it to Gods: there nigh to thee sate all the Holy Ones.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Gods approached the ways of holy Law; there was a gathering vast as heaven itself. The waters feed with praise the growing Babe, born nobly in the womb, the seat of Law.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Like grateful food, like some wide dwelling place, like a fruit-bearing hill, a wholesome stream. Like a steed urged to run in swift career, rushing like Sindhu, who may check his course?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Kin as a brother to his sister floods, he eats the woods as a King eats the rich. When through the forest, urged by wind, he spreads, verily Agni shears the hair of earth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Like a swan sitting in the floods he pants wisest in mind mid men he wakes at morn. A Sage like Soma, sprung from Law, he grew like some young creature, mighty, shining far. Next: HYMN LXVI. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: LIKE the Sun's glance, like wealth of varied sort, like breath which is the life, like one's own son, Like a swift bird, a cow who yields her milk, pure and refulgent to the wood he speeds.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He offers safety like a pleasant home, like ripened corn, the Conqueror of men. Like a Seer lauding, famed among the folk; like a steed friendly he vouchsafes us power.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With flame insatiate, like eternal might; caring for each one like a dame at home; Bright when he shines forth, whitish mid the folk, like a car, gold-decked, thundering to the fight.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He strikes with terror like a dart shot forth, e’en like an archer's arrow tipped with flame; Master of present and of future life, the maidens’ lover and the matrons’ Lord.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To him lead all your ways: may we attain the kindled God as cows their home at eve. He drives the flames below as floods their swell: the rays rise up to the fair place of heaven. Next: HYMN LXVII. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: VICTORIOUS in the wood, Friend among men, ever he claims obedience as a King. Gracious like peace, blessing like mental power, Priest was he, offering-bearer, full of thought.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He, bearing in his hand all manly might, crouched in the cavern, struck the Gods with fear. Men filled with understanding find him there, when they have sting prayers formed within their heart.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He, like the Unborn, holds the broad earth up; and with effective utterance fixed the sky. O Agni, guard the spots which cattle love: thou, life of all, hast gone from lair to lair.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whoso hath known him dwelling in his lair, and hath approached the stream of holy Law,— They who release him, paying sacred rites,—truly to such doth he announce great wealth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He who grows mightily in herbs, within each fruitful mother and each babe she bears, Wise, life of all men, in the waters’ home,—for him have sages built as ’twere a seat. Next: HYMN LXVIII. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: COMMINGLING, restless, he ascends the sky, unveiling nights and all that stands or moves, As he the sole God is preeminent in greatness among all these other Gods.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: All men are joyful in thy power, O God, that living from the dry wood thou art born. All truly share thy Godhead while they keep, in their accustomed ways, eternal Law.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Strong is the thought of Law, the Law's behest; all works have they performed; he quickens all. Whoso will bring oblation, gifts to thee, to him, bethinking thee, vouchsafe thou wealth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Seated as Priest with Manu's progeny, of all these treasures he alone is Lord. Men yearn for children to prolong their line, and are not disappointed in their hope.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Eagerly they who hear his word fulfil his wish as sons obey their sire's behest. He, rich in food, unbars his wealth like doors: he, the House-Friend, hath decked heaven's vault with stars. Next: HYMN LXIX. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: BRIGHT, splendid, like Dawn's lover, he hath filled the two joined worlds as with the light of heaven. When born, with might thou hast encompassed them: Father of Gods, and yet their Son wast thou.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni, the Sage, the humble, who discerns like the cow's udder, the sweet taste of food, Like a bliss-giver to be drawn to men, sits gracious in the middle of the house.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Born in the dwelling like a lovely son, pleased, like a strong steed, he bears on the folk. What time the men and I, with heroes, call, may Agni then gain all through Godlike power.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: None breaks these holy laws of thine when thou hast granted audience to these chieftains here. This is thy boast, thou smotest with thy peers, and joined with heroes dravest off disgrace.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Like the Dawn's lover, spreading light, well-known as hued like morn, may he remember me. They, bearing of themselves, unbar the doors: they all ascend to the fair place of heaven. Next: HYMN LXX. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: MAY we, the pious, win much food by prayer, may Agni with fair light pervade each act,— He the observer of the heavenly laws of Gods, and of the race of mortal man.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He who is germ of waters, germ of woods, germ of all things that move not and that move,— To him even in the rock and in the house: Immortal One, he cares for all mankind.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni is Lord of riches for the man who serves him readily with sacred songs. Protect these beings thou with careful thought, knowing the races both of Gods and men.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whom many dawns and nights, unlike, make strong, whom, born in Law, all things that move and stand,— He hath been won, Herald who sits in light, making effectual all our holy works.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou settest value on our cows and woods: all shall bring tribute to us to the light. Men have served thee in many and sundry spots, parting, as ’twere, an aged father's wealth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Like a brave archer, like one skilled and bold, a fierce avenger, so he shines in fight. Next: HYMN LXXI. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: LOVING the loving One, as wives their husband, the sisters of one home have urged him forward, Bright-coloured, even, as the cows love morning, dark, breaking forth to view, and redly beaming.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Our sires with lauds burst e’en the firm-set fortress, yea, the Aṅgirases, with roar, the mountain. They made for us a way to reach high heaven, they found us day, light, day's sign, beams of morning.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: They stablished order, made his service fruitful; then parting them among the longing faithful, Not thirsting after aught, they come, most active, while with sweet food the race of Gods they strengthen.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Since Mātariśvan, far-diffused, hath stirred him, and he in every house grown bright and noble, He, Bhṛgu-like I hath gone as his companion, as on commission to a greater Sovran.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When man poured juice to Heaven, the mighty Father, he knew and freed himself from close embracement. The archer boldly shot at him his arrow, and the God threw his splendour on his Daughter.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whoso, hath flames for thee within his dwelling, or brings the worship which thou lovest daily, Do thou of double might increase his substance: may he whom thou incitest meet with riches.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: All sacrificial viands wait on Agni as the Seven mighty Rivers seek the ocean. Not by our brethren was our food discovered: find with the Gods care for us, thou who knowest.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When light hath filled the Lord of men for increase, straight from the heaven descends the limpid moisture. Agni hath brought to light and filled with spirit the youthful host blameless and well providing.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He who like thought goes swiftly on his journey, the Sun, alone is ever Lord of riches. The Kings with fair hands, Varuṇa and Mitra, protect the precious nectar in our cattle.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Agni, break not our ancestral friendship, Sage as thou art, endowed with deepest knowledge. Old age, like gathering cloud, impairs the body: before that evil be come nigh protect me. Next: HYMN LXXII. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: THOUGH holding many gifts for men, he humbleth the higher powers of each wise ordainer. Agni is now the treasure-lord of treasures, for ever granting all immortal bounties.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Gods infallible all searching found not him, the dear Babe who still is round about us. Worn weary, following his track, devoted, they reached the lovely highest home of Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Because with holy oil the pure Ones, Agni, served thee the very pure three autumn seasons, Therefore they won them holy names for worship, and nobly born they dignified their bodies.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Making them known to spacious earth and heaven, the holy Ones revealed the powers of Rudra. The mortal band, discerning in the distance, found Agni standing in the loftiest station.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Nigh they approached, one-minded, with their spouses, kneeling to him adorable paid worship. Friend finding in his own friend's eye protection, they made their own the bodies which they chastened.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Soon as the holy beings had discovered the thrice-seven mystic things contained within thee, With these, one-minded, they preserve the Amṛta: guard thou the life of all their plants and cattle.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou, Agni, knower of men's works, hast sent us good food in constant course for our subsistence: Thou deeply skilled in paths of Gods becamest an envoy never wearied, offering-bearer.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Knowing the Law, the seven strong floods from heaven, full of good thought, discerned the doors of riches. Saramā found the cattle's firm-built prison whereby the race of man is still supported.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: They who approached all noble operations making a path that leads to life immortal, To be the Bird's support, the spacious mother, Aditi, and her great Sons stood in power.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When Gods immortal made both eyes of heaven, they gave to him the gift of beauteous glory. Now they flow forth like rivers set in motion: they knew the Red Steeds coming down, O Agni. Next: HYMN LXXIII. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: HE who gives food, like patrimonial riches and guides aright like some wise man's instruction, Loved like a guest who lies in pleasant lodging,—may he, as Priest, prosper his servant's dwelling.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He who like Savitar the God, true-minded protecteth with his power. all acts of vigour, Truthful, like splendour, glorified by many, like breath joy-giving,—all must strive to win him.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He who on earth dwells like a king surrounded by faithful friends, like a God all-sustaining, Like heroes who preside, who sit in safety: like as a blameless dame dear to her husband.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thee, such, in settlements secure, O Agni, our men serve ever kindled in each dwelling. On him have they laid splendour in abundance: dear to all men, bearer be he of riches.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May thy rich worshippers win food, O Agni, and princes gain long life who bring oblation. May we get booty from our foe in battle, presenting to the Gods their share for glory.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The cows of holy law, sent us by Heaven, have swelled with laden udders, loudly lowing; Soliciting his favour, from a distance the rivers to the rock have flowed together.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni, with thee, soliciting thy favour, the holy Ones have gained glory in heaven. They made the Night and Dawn of different colours, and set the black and purple hues together.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May we and those who worship be the mortals whom thou, O Agni, leadest on to riches. Thou hast filled earth and heaven and air's mid-region, and followest the whole world like a shadow.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Aided by thee, O Agni, may we conquer steeds with steeds, men with men, heroes with heroes, Lords of the wealth transmitted by our fathers: and may our princes live a hundred winters.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May these our hymns of praise, Agni, Ordainer, be pleasant to thee in thy heart and spirit. May we have power to hold thy steeds of riches, laying on thee the God-sent gift of glory. Next: HYMN LXXIV. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As forth to sacrifice we go, a hymn to a hymn let us say, Who hears us even when afar;

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Who, from of old, in carnage, when the people gathered, hath preserved His household for the worshipper.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: And let men say, Agni is born, e’en he who slayeth Vṛtra, he Who winneth wealth in every fight.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Him in whose house an envoy thou lovest to taste his offered gifts, And strengthenest his sacrifice,

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Him, Aṅgiras, thou Son of Strength, all men call happy in his God, His offerings, and his sacred grass.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Hitherward shalt thou bring these Gods to our laudation and to taste. These offered gifts, fair-shining One.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
