text: When, Agni, on thine embassage thou goest not a sound is heard of steed or straining of thy car.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Aided by thee uninjured, strong, one after other, goes he forth: Agni, the offerer forward steps.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: And splendid strength, heroic, high, Agni, thou grantest from the Gods, Thou God, to him who offers gifts. Next: HYMN LXXV. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: ACCEPT our loudest-sounding hymn, food most delightful to the Gods, Pouring our offerings in thy mouth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Now, Agni, will we say to thee, O wisest and best Aṅgiras, Our precious, much-availing prayer.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Who, Agni, is thy kin, of men? who is thy worthy worshipper? On whom dependent? who art thou?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The kinsman, Agni, of mankind, their well beloved Friend art thou, A Friend whom friends may supplicate.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Bring to us Mitra, Varuṇa, bring the Gods to mighty sacrifice. Bring them, O Agni, to thine home. Next: HYMN LXXVI. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: How may the mind draw nigh to please thee, Agni? What hymn of praise shall bring us greatest blessing? Or who hath gained thy power by sacrifices? or with what mind shall we bring thee oblations?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come hither, Agni; sit thee down as Hotar; be thou who never wast deceived our leader. May Heaven and Earth, the all-pervading, love thee: worship the Gods to win for us their favour.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Burn thou up all the Rākṣasas, O Agni; ward thou off curses from our sacrifices. Bring hither with his Bays the Lord of Soma: here is glad welcome for the Bounteous Giver.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou Priest with lip and voice that bring us children hast been invoked. Here with the Gods be seated. Thine is the task of Cleanser and Presenter: waken us, Wealth-bestower and Producer.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As with oblations of the priestly Manus thou worshippedst the Gods, a Sage with sages, So now, O truthfullest Invoker Agni, worship this day with joy-bestowing ladle. Next: HYMN LXXVII. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: How shall we pay oblation unto Agni? What hymn, Godloved, is said to him refulgent? Who, deathless, true to Law, mid men a herald, bringeth the Gods as best of sacrificers?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Bring him with reverence hither, most propitious in sacrifices, true to Law, the herald; For Agni, when he seeks the Gods for mortals, knows them full well and worships them in spirit.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For he is mental power, a man, and perfect; he is the bringer, friend-like, of the wondrous. The pious Āryan tribes at sacrifices address them first to him who doeth marvels.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May Agni, foe-destroyer, manliest Hero, accept with love our hymns and our devotion. So may the liberal lords whose strength is strongest, urged by their riches, stir our thoughts with vigour.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thus Agni Jātavedas, true to Order, hath by the priestly Gotamas been lauded. May he augment in them splendour and vigour: observant, as he lists, he gathers increase. Next: HYMN LXXVIII. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O JĀTAVEDAS, keen and swift, we Gotamas with sacred song exalt thee for thy glories' sake.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thee, as thou art, desiring wealth Gotama worships with his song: We laud thee for thy glories' sake.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As such, like Aṅgiras we call on thee best winner of the spoil: We laud thee for thy glories' sake.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thee, best of Vṛtra-slayers, thee who shakest off our Dasyu foes: We laud thee for thy glories' sake.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: A pleasant song to Agni we, sons of Rahūgaṅa, have sung: We laud thee for thy glories' sake. Next: HYMN LXXIX. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: HE in mid-air's expanse hath golden tresses; a raging serpent, like the rushing tempest: Purely refulgent, knowing well the morning; like honourable dames, true, active workers.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thy well-winged flashes strengthen in their manner, when the black Bull hath bellowed round about us. With drops that bless and seem to smile he cometh: the waters fall, the clouds utter their thunder.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When he comes streaming with the milk of worship, conducting by directest paths of Order Aryaman, Mitra, Varuṇa, Parijman fill the hide full where lies the nether press-stone.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Agni, thou who art the lord of wealth in kine, thou Son of Strength, Vouchsafe to us, O Jātavedas, high renown.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He, Agni, kindled, good and wise, must be exalted in our song: Shine, thou of many forms, shine radiantly on us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Agni, shining of thyself by night and when the morning breaks, Burn, thou whose teeth are sharp, against the Rākṣasas.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Adorable in all our rites, favour us, Agni, with thine aid, When the great hymn is chanted forth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Bring to us ever-conquering wealth, wealth, Agni, worthy of our choice, In all our frays invincible.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Give us, O Agni, through thy grace wealth that supporteth all our life, Thy favour so that we may live.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Gotama, desiring bliss present thy songs composed with care To Agni of the pointed flames.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May the man fall, O Agni, who near or afar assaileth us: Do thou increase and prosper us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Keen and swift Agni, thousand-eyed, chaseth the Rākṣasas afar: He singeth, herald meet for lauds. Next: HYMN LXXX. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: THUS in the Soma, in wild joy the Brahman hath exalted thee: Thou, mightiest thunder-armed, hast driven by force the Dragon from the earth, lauding thine own imperial sway.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The mighty flowing Soma-draught, brought by the Hawk, hath gladdened thee, That in thy strength, O Thunderer, thou hast struck down Vṛtra from the floods, lauding thine own imperial sway.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Go forward, meet the foe, be bold; thy bolt of thunder is not checked. Manliness, Indra, is thy might: stay Vṛtra, make the waters thine, lauding thine own imperial sway.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou smotest Vṛtra from the earth, smotest him, Indra, from the sky. Let these life-fostering waters flow attended by the Marut host, lauding thine own imperial sway.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The wrathful Indra with his bolt of thunder rushing on the foe, Smote fierce on trembling Vṛtra's back, and loosed the waters free to run, lauding his own imperial sway.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With hundred-jointed thunderbolt Indra hath struck him on the back, And, while rejoicing in the juice, seeketh prosperity for friends, lauding his own imperial sway.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra, unconquered might is thine, Thunderer, Caster of the Stone; For thou with thy surpassing power smotest to death the guileful beast, lauding thine own imperial sway.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Far over ninety spacious floods thy thunderbolts were cast abroad: Great, Indra, is thy hero might, and strength is seated in thine arms, lauding thine own imperial sway.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Laud him a thousand all at once, shout twenty forth the hymn of praise. Hundreds have sung aloud to him, to Indra hath the prayer been raised, lauding his own imperial sway.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra hath smitten down the power of Vṛtra,—might with stronger might. This was his manly exploit, he slew Vṛtra and let loose the floods, lauding his own imperial sway.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Yea, even this great Pair of Worlds trembled in terror at thy wrath, When, Indra, Thunderer, Marut-girt, thou slewest Vṛtra in thy strength, lauding thine own imperial sway.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: But Vṛtra scared not Indra with his shaking or his thunder roar. On him that iron thunderbolt fell fiercely with its thousand points, lauding his own imperial sway.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When with the thunder thou didst make thy dart and Vṛtra meet in war, Thy might, O Indra, fain to slay the Dragon, was set firm in heaven, lauding thine own imperial sway.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When at thy shout, O Thunder-armed, each thing both fixed and moving shook, E’en Tvaṣṭar trembled at thy wrath and quaked with fear because of thee, lauding thine own imperial sway.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: There is not, in our knowledge, one who passeth Indra in his strength: In him the Deities have stored manliness, insight, power and might, lauding his own imperial sway.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Still as of old, whatever rite Atharvan, Manus sire of all, Dadhyach performed, their prayer and praise united in that Indra meet, lauding his own imperial sway. Next: HYMN LXXXI. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: THE men have lifted Indra up, the Vṛtra slayer, to joy and strength: Him, verily, we invocate in battles whether great or small: be he our aid in deeds of might.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou, Hero, art a warrior, thou art giver of abundant spoil. Strengthening e’en the feeble, thou aidest the sacrificer, thou givest the offerer ample wealth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When war and battles are on foot, booty is laid before the bold. Yoke thou thy wildly-rushing Bays. Whom wilt thou slay and whom enrich? Do thou, O Indra, make us rich.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Mighty through wisdom, as he lists, terrible, he hath waxed in strength. Lord of Bay Steeds, strong-jawed, sublime, he in joined hands for glory's sake hath grasped his iron thunderbolt.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He filled the earthly atmosphere and pressed against the lights in heaven. None like thee ever hath been born, none, Indra, will be born like thee. Thou hast waxed mighty over all.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May he who to the offerer gives the foeman's man-sustaining food, May Indra lend his aid to us. Deal forth—abundant is thy wealth—that in thy bounty I may share.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He, righteous-hearted, at each time of rapture gives us herds of kine. Gather in both thy hands for us treasures of many hundred sorts. Sharpen thou us, and bring us wealth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Refresh thee, Hero, with the juice outpoured for bounty and for strength. We know thee Lord of ample store, to thee have sent our hearts' desires: be therefore our Protector thou.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: These people, Indra, keep for thee all that is worthy of thy choice. Discover thou, as Lord, the wealth of men who offer up no gifts: bring thou to us this wealth of theirs. Next: HYMN LXXXII. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: GRACIOUSLY listen to our songs, Maghavan, be not negligent. As thou hast made us full of joy and lettest us solicit thee, now, Indra, yoke thy two Bay Steeds.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Well have they eaten and rejoiced; the friends have risen and passed away. The sages luminous in themselves have. praised thee with their latest hymn. Now, Indra, yoke thy two Bay Steeds.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Maghavan, we will reverence thee who art so fair to look upon. Thus praised, according to our wish come now with richly laden car. Now, Indra, yoke thy two Bay Steeds.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He will in very truth ascend the powerful car that finds the kine, Who thinks upon the well-filled bowl, the Tawny Coursers' harnesser. Now, Indra, yoke thy two Bay Steeds.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Let, Lord of Hundred Powers, thy Steeds be harnessed on the right and left. Therewith in rapture of the juice, draw near to thy beloved Spouse. Now, Indra, yoke thy two Bay Steeds.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With holy prayer I yoke thy long-maned pair of Bays: come hitherward; thou holdest them in both thy hands. The stirring draughts of juice outpoured have made thee glad: thou, Thunderer, hast rejoiced with Pūṣan and thy Spouse. Next: HYMN LXXXIII. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: INDRA, the mortal man well guarded by thine aid goes foremost in the wealth of horses and of kine. With amplest wealth thou fillest him, as round about the waters clearly seen afar fill Sindhu full.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The heavenly Waters come not nigh the priestly bowl: they but look down and see how far mid-air is spread: The Deities conduct the pious man to them: like suitors they delight in him who loveth prayer.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Praiseworthy blessing hast thou laid upon the pair who with uplifted ladle serve thee, man and wife. Unchecked he dwells and prospers in thy law: thy power brings blessing to the sacrificer pouring gifts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: First the Aṅgirases won themselves vital power, whose fires were kindled through good deeds and sacrifice. The men together found the Paṇi's hoarded wealth, the cattle, and the wealth in horses and in kine.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Atharvan first by sacrifices laid the paths then, guardian of the Law, sprang up the loving Sun. Uśanā Kāvya straightway hither drove the kine. Let us with offerings honour Yama's deathless birth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When sacred grass is trimmed to aid the auspicious work, or the hymn makes its voice of praise sound to the sky. Where the stone rings as ’twere a singer skilled in laud,—Indra in truth delights when these come near to him. Next: HYMN LXXXIV. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Soma hath been pressed for thee, O Indra; mightiest, bold One, come. May Indra-vigour fill thee full, as the Sun fills mid-air with rays.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: His pair of Tawny Coursers bring Indra of unresisted might Hither to Ṛṣis’ songs of praise and sacrifice performed by men.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Slayer of Vṛtra, mount thy car; thy Bay Steeds have been yoked by prayer. May, with its voice, the pressing-stone draw thine attention hitherward.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This poured libation, Indra, drink, immortal, gladdening, excellent. Streams of the bright have flowed to thee here at the seat of holy Law.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Sing glory now to Indra, say to him your solemn eulogies. The drops poured forth have made him glad: pay reverence to his might supreme.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When, Indra, thou dost yoke thy Steeds, there is no better charioteer: None hath surpassed thee in thy might, none with good steeds o’ertaken thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He who alone bestoweth on mortal man who offereth gifts, The ruler of resistless power, is Indra, sure.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When will he trample, like a weed, the man who hath no gift for him? When, verily, will Indra hear our songs of praise?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He who with Soma juice prepared amid the many honours thee,— Verily Indra gains thereby tremendous might.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The juice of Soma thus diffused, sweet to the taste, the bright cows drink, Who for the sake of splendour close to mighty Indra's side rejoice, good in their own supremacy.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Craving his touch the dappled kine mingle the Soma with their milk. The milch-kine dear to Indra send forth his death-dealing thunderbolt, good in their own supremacy.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With veneration, passing wise, honouring his victorious might, They follow close his many laws to win them due preeminence, good in their own supremacy.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With bones of Dadhyach for his arms, Indra, resistless in attack, Struck nine-and-ninety Vṛtras dead.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He, searching for the horse's head, removed among the mountains, found At Śaryaṇāvān what he sought.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Then verily they recognized the essential form of Tvaṣṭar's Bull, Here in the mansion of the Moon.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Who yokes to-day unto the pole of Order the strong and passionate steers of checkless spirit, With shaft-armed mouths, heart-piercing, health-bestowing? Long shall he live who richly pays their service.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Who fleeth forth? who suffereth? who feareth? Who knoweth Indra present, Indra near us? Who sendeth benediction on his offspring, his household, wealth and person, and the People?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Who with poured oil and offering honours Agni, with ladle worships at appointed seasons? To whom to the Gods bring oblation quickly? What offerer, God-favoured, knows him thoroughly?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou as a God, O Mightiest, verily blessest mortal man. O Maghavan, there is no comforter but thou: Indra, I speak my words to thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Let not thy bounteous gifts, let not thy saving help fail us, good Lord, at any time; And measure out to us, thou lover of mankind, all riches hitherward from men. Next: HYMN LXXXV. Maruts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: THEY who are glancing forth, like women, on their way, doers of mighty deeds, swift racers, Rudra's Sons, The Maruts have made heaven and earth increase and grow: in sacrifices they delight, the strong and wild.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Grown to their perfect strength greatness have they attained; the Rudras have established their abode in heaven. Singing their song of praise and generating might, they have put glory on, the Sons whom Pṛśni bare.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When, Children of the Cow, they shine in bright attire, and on their fair limbs lay their golden ornaments, They drive away each adversary from their path, and, following their traces, fatness floweth down,

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When, mighty Warriors, ye who glitter with your spears, o’erthrowing with your strength e’en what is ne’er o’erthrown, When, O ye Maruts, ye the host that send the rain, had harnessed to your cars the thought-fleet spotted deer.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When ye have harnessed to your cars the spotted deer, urging the thunderbolt, O Maruts, to the fray, Forth rush the torrents of the dark red stormy cloud, and moisten, like a skin, the earth with water-floods.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Let your swift-gliding coursers bear you hitherward with their fleet pinions. Come ye forward with your arms. Sit on the grass; a wide seat hath been made for you: delight yourselves, O Maruts, in the pleasant food.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Strong in their native strength to greatness have they grown, stepped to the firmament and made their dwelling wide. When Viṣṇu saved the Soma bringing wild delight, the Maruts sate like birds on their dear holy grass.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: In sooth like heroes fain for fight they rush about, like combatants fame-seeking have they striven in war. Before the Maruts every creature is afraid: the men are like to Kings, terrible to behold.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When Tvaṣṭar deft of hand had turned the thunderbolt, golden, with thousand edges, fashioned more skilfully, Indra received it to perform heroic deeds. Vṛtra he slew, and forced the flood of water forth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: They with their vigorous strength pushed the well up on high, and clove the cloud in twain though it was passing strong. The Maruts, bounteous Givers, sending forth their voice, in the wild joy of Soma wrought their glorious deeds.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: They drave the cloud transverse directed hitherward, and poured the fountain forth for thirsting Gotama. Shining with varied light they come to him with help: they with their might fulfilled the longing of the sage.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The shelters which ye have for him who lauds you, bestow them threefold on the man who offers. Extend the same boons unto us, ye Maruts. Give us, O Heroes, wealth with noble offspring. Next: HYMN LXXXVI. Maruts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: THE best of guardians hath that man within whose dwelling place ye drink, O Maruts, giants of the sky.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Honoured with sacrifice or with the worship of the sages’ hymns, O Maruts, listen to the call.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Yea, the strong man to whom ye have vouchsafed to give a sage, shall move Into a stable rich in kine.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Upon this hero's sacred grass Soma is poured in daily rites: Praise and delight are sung aloud.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Let the strong Maruts hear him, him surpassing all men: strength be his That reaches even to the Sun.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For, through the swift Gods’ loving help, in many an autumn, Maruts, we Have offered up our sacrifice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Fortunate shall that mortal be, O Maruts most adorable, Whose offerings ye bear away.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Heroes truly strong, ye know the toil of him who sings your praise, The heart's desire of him who loves.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O ye of true strength, make this thing manifest by your greatness: strike The demon with your thunderbolt.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Conceal the horrid darkness, drive far from us each devouring fiend. Create the light for which we long. Next: HYMN LXXXVII. Maruts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: LOUD Singers, never humbled, active, full of strength, immovable, impetuous, manliest, best-beloved, They have displayed themselves with glittering ornaments, a few in number only, like the heavens with stars.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When, Maruts, on the steeps ye pile the moving cloud, ye are like birds on whatsoever path it be. Clouds everywhere shed forth the rain upon your cars. Drop fatness, honey-hued, for him who sings your praise.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Earth at their racings trembles as if weak and worn, when on their ways they yoke their cars for victory. They, sportive, loudly roaring, armed with glittering spears, shakers of all, themselves admire their mightiness.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Self-moving is that youthful band, with spotted steeds; thus it hath lordly sway, endued with power and might. Truthful art thou, and blameless, searcher out of sin: so thou, Strong Host, wilt be protector of this prayer.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We speak by our descent from our primeval Sire; our tongue, when we behold the Soma, stirs itself. When, shouting, they had joined Indra in toil of fight, then only they obtained their sacrificial names.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Splendours they gained for glory, they who wear bright rings; rays they obtained, and men to celebrate their praise. Armed with their swords, impetuous and fearing naught, they have possessed the Maruts’ own beloved home. Next: HYMN LXXXVIII. Maruts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: COME hither, Maruts, on your lightning laden cars, sounding with sweet songs, armed with lances, winged with steeds. Fly unto us with noblest food, like birds, O ye of mighty power.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With their red-hued or, haply, tawny coursers which speed their chariots on, they come for glory. Brilliant like gold is he who holds the thunder. Earth have they smitten with the chariot's felly.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For beauty ye have swords upon your bodies. As they stir woods so may they stir our spirits. For your sake, O ye Maruts very mighty and well-born, have they set the stone, in motion.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The days went round you and came back O yearners, back, to this prayer and to this solemn worship. The Gotamas making their prayer with singing have pushed the well's lid up to drink the water.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: No hymn way ever known like this aforetime which Gotama sang forth for you, O Maruts, What time upon your golden wheels he saw you, wild boars rushing about with tusks of iron.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To you this freshening draught of Soma rusheth, O Maruts, like the voice of one who prayeth. It rusheth freely from our hands as these libations wont to flow. Next: HYMN LXXXIX. Viśvedevas.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: MAY powers auspicious come to us from every side, never deceived, unhindered, and victorious, That the Gods ever may be with us for our gain, our guardians day by day unceasing in their care.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May the auspicious favour of the Gods be ours, on us descend the bounty of the righteous Gods. The friendship of the Gods have we devoutly sought: so may the Gods extend our life that we may live.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We call them hither with a hymn of olden time, Bhaga, the friendly Dakṣa, Mitra, Aditi, Aryaman, Varuṇa, Soma, the Aśvins. May Sarasvatī, auspicious, grant felicity.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May the Wind waft to us that pleasant medicine, may Earth our Mother give it, and our Father Heaven, And the joy-giving stones that press the Soma's juice. Aśvins, may ye, for whom our spirits long, hear this.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Him we invoke for aid who reigns supreme, the Lord of all that stands or moves, inspirer of the soul, That Pūṣan may promote the increase of our wealth, our keeper and our guard infallible for our good.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Illustrious far and wide, may Indra prosper us: may Pūṣan prosper us, the Master of all wealth. May Tārkṣya with uninjured fellies prosper us: Bṛhaspati vouchsafe to us prosperity.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Maruts, Sons of Pṛśni, borne by spotted steeds, moving in glory, oft visiting holy rites, Sages whose tongue is Agni, brilliant as the Sun,—hither let all the Gods for our protection come.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Gods, may we with our ears listen to what is good, and with our eyes see what is good, ye Holy Ones. With limbs and bodies firm may we extolling you attain the term of life appointed by the Gods.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: A hundred autumns stand before us, O ye Gods, within whose space ye bring our bodies to decay; Within whose space our sons become fathers in turn. Break ye not in the midst our course of fleeting life.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Aditi is the heaven, Aditi is mid-air, Aditi is the Mother and the Sire and Son. Aditi is all Gods, Aditi five-classed men, Aditi all that hath been born and shall be born. Next: HYMN XC. Viśvedevas.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: MAY Varuṇa with guidance straight, and Mitra lead us, he who knows, And Aryaman in accord with Gods.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For they are dealers forth of wealth, and, not deluded, with their might Guard evermore the holy laws.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Shelter may they vouchsafe to us, Immortal Gods to mortal men, Chasing our enemies away.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May they mark out our paths to bliss, Indra, the Maruts, Pūṣan, and Bhaga, the Gods to be adored.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Yea, Pūṣan, Viṣṇu, ye who run your course, enrich our hymns with kine; Bless us with all prosperity.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The winds waft sweets, the rivers pour sweets for the man who keeps the Law So may the plants be sweet for us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Sweet be the night and sweet the dawns, sweet the terrestrial atmosphere; Sweet be our Father Heaven to us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May the tall tree be full of sweets for us, and full of sweets the Sun: May our milch-kine be sweet for us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Be Mitra gracious unto us, and Varuṇa and Aryaman: Indra, Bṛhaspati be kind, and Viṣṇu of the mighty stride. Next: HYMN XCI. Soma.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou, Soma, art preeminent for wisdom; along the straightest path thou art our leader. Our wise forefathers by thy guidance, Indu, dealt out among the Gods their share of treasure.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou by thine insight art most wise, O Soma, strong by thine energies and all possessing, Mighty art thou by all thy powers and greatness, by glories art thou glorious, guide of mortals.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thine are King Varuṇa's eternal statutes, lofty and deep, O Soma, is thy glory. All-pure art thou like Mitra the beloved, adorable, like Aryaman, O Soma.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With all thy glories on the earth, in heaven, on mountains, in the plants, and in the waters,— With all of these, well-pleased and not in anger, accept, O royal Soma, our oblations.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou, Soma, art the Lord of heroes, King, yea, Vṛtra-slayer thou: Thou art auspicious energy.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: And, Soma, let it be thy wish that we may live and may not die: Praise-loving Lord of plants art thou.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To him who keeps the law, both old and young, thou givest happiness, And energy that he may live.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Guard us, King Soma, on all sides from him who threatens us: never let The friend of one like thee be harmed.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With those delightful aids which thou hast, Soma, for the worshipper,— Even with those protect thou us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Accepting this our sacrifice and this our praise, O Soma, come, And be thou nigh to prosper us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Well-skilled in speech we magnify thee, Soma, with our sacred songs: Come thou to us, most gracious One.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Enricher, healer of disease, wealth-finder, prospering our store, Be, Soma, a good Friend to us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Soma, be happy in our heart, as milch-kine in the grassy meads, As a young man in his own house.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Soma, God, the mortal man who in thy friendship hath delight, Him doth the mighty Sage befriend.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Save us from slanderous reproach, keep us., O Soma, from distress: Be unto us a gracious Friend.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Soma, wax great. From every side may vigorous powers unite in thee: Be in the gathering-place of strength.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Wax, O most gladdening Soma, great through all thy rays of light, and be A Friend of most illustrious fame to prosper us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: In thee be juicy nutriments united, and powers and mighty foe-subduing vigour, Waxing to immortality, O Soma: win highest glories for thyself in heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Such of thy glories as with poured oblations men honour, may they all invest our worship. Wealth-giver, furtherer with troops of heroes, sparing the brave, come, Soma, to our houses.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To him who worships Soma gives the milch-cow, a fleet steed and a man of active knowledge, Skilled in home duties, meet for holy synod, for council meet, a glory to his father.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Invincible in fight, saver in battles, guard of our camp, winner of light and water, Born amid hymns, well-housed, exceeding famous, victor, in thee will we rejoice, O Soma.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: These herbs, these milch-kine, and these running waters, all these, O Soma, thou hast generated. The spacious firmament hast thou expanded, and with the light thou hast dispelled the darkness.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Do thou, God Soma, with thy Godlike spirit, victorious, win for us a share of riches. Let none prevent thee: thou art Lord of valour. Provide for both sides in the fray for booty. Next: HYMN XCII. Dawn.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: THESE Dawns have raised their banner; in the eastern half of the mid-air they spread abroad their shining light. Like heroes who prepare their weapons for the war, onward they come bright red in hue, the Mother Cows.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Readily have the purple beams of light shot up; the Red Cows have they harnessed, easy to be yoked. The Dawns have brought distinct perception as before: red-hued, they have attained their fulgent brilliancy.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: They sing their song like women active in their tasks, along their common path hither from far away, Bringing refreshment to the liberal devotee, yea, all things to the worshipper who pours the juice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: She, like a dancer, puts her broidered garments on: as a cow yields her udder so she bares her breast. Creating light for all the world of life, the Dawn hath laid the darkness open as the cows their stall.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We have beheld the brightness of her shining; it spreads and drives away the darksome monster. Like tints that deck the Post at sacrifices, Heaven's Daughter hath attained her wondrous splendour.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We have o’erpast the limit of this darkness; Dawn breaking forth again brings clear perception. She like a flatterer smiles in light for glory, and fair of face hath wakened to rejoice us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Gotamas have praised Heaven's radiant Daughter, the leader of the charm of pleasant voices. Dawn, thou conferrest on us strength with offspring and men, conspicuous with kine and horses.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O thou who shinest forth in wondrous glory, urged onward by thy strength, auspicious Lady, Dawn, may I gain that wealth, renowned and ample, in brave sons, troops of slaves, far-famed for horses.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Bending her looks on all the world, the Goddess shines, widely spreading with her bright eye westward. Waking to motion every living creature, she understands the voice of each adorer.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ancient of days, again again born newly, decking her beauty with the self-same raiment. The Goddess wastes away the life of mortals, like a skilled hunter cutting birds in pieces.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: She hath appeared discovering heaven's borders: to the far distance she drives off her Sister. Diminishing the days of human creatures, the Lady shines with all her lover's splendour.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The bright, the blessed One shines forth extending her rays like kine, as a flood rolls his waters. Never transgressing the divine commandments, she is beheld visible with the sunbeams.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Dawn enriched with ample wealth, bestow on us the wondrous gift Wherewith we may support children and children's sons.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou radiant mover of sweet sounds, with wealth of horses and of kine Shine thou on us this day, O Dawn auspiciously.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Dawn enriched with holy rites, yoke to thy car thy purple steeds, And then bring thou unto us all felicities.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Aśvins wonderful in act, do ye unanimous direct Your chariot to our home wealthy in kine and gold.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ye who brought down the hymn from heaven, a light that giveth light to man, Do ye, O Aśvins, bring strength hither unto us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Hither may they who wake at dawn bring, to drink Soma both the Gods Health-givers Wonder-Workers, borne on paths of gold. Next: HYMN XCIII. Agni-Soma.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: AGNI and Soma, mighty Pair, graciously hearken to my call, Accept in friendly wise my hymn, and prosper him who offers gifts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The man who honours you to-day, Agni and Soma, with this hymn, Bestow on him heroic strength, increase of kine, and noble steeds.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The man who offers holy oil and burnt oblations unto you, Agni and Soma, shall enjoy great strength, with offspring, all his life.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni and Soma, famed is that your. prowess wherewith ye stole the kine, his food, from Paṇi. Ye caused the brood of Bṛsaya to perish; ye found the light, the single light for many.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni and Soma, joined in operation ye have set up the shining lights in heaven. From curse and from reproach, Agni and Soma, ye freed the rivers that were bound in fetters.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: One of you Mātariśvan brought from heaven, the Falcon rent the other from the mountain. Strengthened by holy prayer Agni and Soma have made us ample room for sacrificing.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Taste, Agni, Soma, this prepared oblation; accept it, Mighty Ones, and let it please you. Vouchsafe us good protection and kind favour: grant to the sacrificer health and riches.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whoso with oil and poured oblation honours, with God-devoted heart, Agni and Soma,— Protect his sacrifice, preserve him from distress, grant to the sacrificer great felicity.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Invoked together, mates in wealth, Agni-Soma, accept our hymns: Together be among the Gods.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni and Soma, unto him who worships you with holy oil Shine forth an ample recompense.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni and Soma, be ye pleased with these oblations brought to you, And come, together, nigh to us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni and Soma, cherish well our horses, and let our cows be fat who yield oblations. Grant power to us and to our wealthy patrons, and cause our holy rites to be successful. Next: HYMN XCIV. Agni

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: FOR Jātavedas worthy of our praise will we frame with our mind this eulogy as ’twere a car. For good, in his assembly, is this care of ours. Let us not, in thy friendship, Agni, suffer harm.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The man for whom thou sacrificest prospereth, dwelleth without a foe, gaineth heroic might. He waxeth strong, distress never approacheth him. Let us not, in thy friendship, Agni, suffer harm.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May we have power to kindle thee. Fulfil our thoughts. In thee the Gods eat the presented offering, Bring hither the Ādityas, for we long for them. Let us not in thy friendship, Agni, suffer harm.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We will bring fuel and prepare burnt offerings, reminding thee at each successive festival. Fulfil our thought that so we may prolong our lives. Let us not in thy friendship, Agni, suffer harm.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: His ministers move forth, the guardians of the folk, protecting quadruped and biped with their rays. Mighty art thou, the wondrous herald of the Dawn. Let us not in thy friendship, Agni, suffer harm.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou art Presenter and the chief Invoker, thou Director, Purifier, great High Priest by birth. Knowing all priestly work thou perfectest it, Sage. Let us not in thy friendship, Agni, suffer harm.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Lovely of form art thou, alike on every side; though far, thou shinest brightly as if close at hand. O God, thou seest through even the dark of night. Let us not in thy friendship, Agni, suffer harm.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Gods, foremost be his car who pours libations out, and let our hymn prevail o’er evil-hearted men. Attend to this our speech and make it prosper well. Let us not in thy friendship, Agni, suffer harm.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Smite with thy weapons those of evil speech and thought, devouring demons, whether near or tar away. Then to the singer give free way for sacrifice. Let us not in thy friendship, Agni, suffer harm.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When to thy chariot thou hadst yoked two red steeds and two ruddy steeds, wind-sped, thy roar was like a bull's. Thou with smoke-bannered flame attackest forest trees. Let us not in thy friendship, Agni, suffer harm.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Then at thy roar the very birds are terrified, when, eating-up the grass, thy sparks fly forth abroad. Then is it easy for thee and thy car to pass. Let us not in thy friendship, Agni, suffer harm.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He hath the Power to soothe Mitra and Varuṇa: wonderful is the Maruts’ wrath when they descend. Be gracious; let their hearts he turned to us again. Let us not in thy friendship, Agni, suffer harm.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou art a God, thou art the wondrous Friend of Gods, the Vasu of the Vasus, fair in sacrifice. Under, thine own most wide protection may we dwell. Let us not in thy friendship, Agni, suffer harm.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This is thy grace that, kindled in thine own abode, invoked with Soma thou soundest forth most benign, Thou givest wealth and treasure to the worshipper. Let us not in thy friendship, Agni, suffer harm.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To whom thou, Lord of goodly riches, grantest freedom from every sin with perfect wholeness, Whom with good strength thou quickenest , with children and wealth—may we be they, Eternal Being.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Such, Agni, thou who knowest all good fortune, God, lengthen here the days of our existence. This prayer of ours may Varuṇa grant, and Mitra, and Aditi and Sindhu, Earth and Heaven. Next: HYMN XCV. Agni

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To fair goals travel Two unlike in semblance: each in succession nourishes an infant. One bears a Godlike Babe of golden colour; bright and fair-shining, is he with the other.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Tvaṣṭar's ten daughters, vigilant and youthful, produced this Infant borne to sundry quarters. They bear around him whose long flames are pointed, fulgent among mankind with native splendour.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Three several places of his birth they honour, in mid-air, in the heaven, and in the waters. Governing in the east of earthly regions, the seasons hath he stablished in their order.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Who of you knows this secret One? The Infant by his own nature hath brought forth his Mothers. The germ of many, from the waters' bosom he goes forth, wise and great, of Godlike nature.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Visible, fair, he grows in native brightness uplifted in the lap of waving waters. When he was born both Tvaṣṭar's worlds were frightened: they turn to him and reverence the Lion.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Two auspicious Ones, like women, tend him: like lowing cows they seek him in their manner. He is the Lord of Might among the mighty; him, on the right, they balm with their oblations.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Like Savitar his arms with might he stretches; awful, he strives grasping the world's two borders. He forces out from all a brilliant vesture, yea, from his Mothers draws he forth new raiment.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He makes him a most noble form of splendour, decking him in his home with milk and waters. The Sage adorns the depths of air with wisdom: this is the meeting where the Gods are worshipped.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Wide through the firmament spreads forth triumphant the far-resplendent strength of thee the Mighty. Kindled by us do thou preserve us, Agni, with all thy self-bright undiminished succours.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: In dry spots he makes stream, and course, and torrent, and inundates the earth with floods that glisten. All ancient things within his maw he gathers, and moves among the new fresh-sprouting grasses.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Fed with our fuel, purifying Agni, so blaze to us auspiciously for glory. This prayer of ours may Varuṇa grant, and Mitra, and Aditi and Sindhu, Earth and Heaven. Next: HYMN XCVI. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: HE in the ancient way by strength engendered, lo! straight hath taken to himself all wisdom. The waters and the bowl have made him friendly. The Gods possessed the wealth bestowing Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: At Āyu's ancient call he by his wisdom gave all this progeny of men their being, And, by refulgent light, heaven and the waters. The Gods possessed the wealth. bestowing Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Praise him, ye Āryan folk, as chief performer of sacrifice adored and ever toiling, Well-tended, Son of Strength, the Constant Giver. The Gods possessed the wealth bestowing Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: That Mātariśvan rich in wealth and treasure, light-winner, finds a pathway for his offspring. Guard of our folk, Father of earth and heaven. The Gods possessed the wealth bestowing Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Night and Dawn, changing each the other's colour, meeting together suckle one same Infant: Golden between the heaven and earth he shineth. The Gods possessed the wealth bestowing Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Root of wealth, gathering-place of treasures, banner of sacrifice, who grants the suppliant's wishes: Preserving him as their own life immortal, the Gods possessed the wealth-bestowing Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Now and of old the home of wealth, the mansion of what is born and what was born aforetime, Guard of what is and what will be hereafter,—the Gods possessed the wealth bestowing Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May the Wealth-Giver grant us conquering riches; may the Wealth-Giver grant us wealth with heroes. May the Wealth-Giver grant us food with offspring, and length of days may the Wealth-Giver send us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Fed with our fuel, purifying Agni, so blaze to us auspiciously for glory. This prayer of ours may Varuṇa grant, and Mitra, and Aditi and Sindhu, Earth and Heaven. Next: HYMN XCVII. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: CHASING with light our sin away, O Agni, shine thou wealth on us. May his light chase our sin away.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For goodly fields, for pleasant homes, for wealth we sacrifice to thee. May his light chase our sin away.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Best praiser of all these be he; foremost, our chiefs who sacrifice. May his light chase our sin away.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So that thy worshippers and we, thine, Agni, in our sons may live. May his light chase our sin away.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As ever-conquering Agni's beams of splendour go to every side, May his light chase our sin away.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To every side thy face is turned, thou art triumphant everywhere. May his light chase our sin away.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O thou whose face looks every way, bear us past foes as in a ship. May his light chase our sin away.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As in a ship, convey thou us for our advantage o’er the flood. May his light chase our sin away. Next: HYMN XCVIII. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: STILL in Vaiśvānara's grace may we continue: yea, he is King supreme o’er all things living. Sprung hence to life upon this All he looketh. Vaiśvānara hath rivalry with Sūrya.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Present in heaven, in earth, all-present Agni,—all plants that grow on ground hath he pervaded. May Agni, may Vaiśvānara with vigour, present, preserve us day and night from foemen.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Be this thy truth, Vaiśvānara, to us-ward: let wealth in rich abundance gather round us. This prayer of ours may Varuṇa grant, and Mitra, and Aditi and Sindhu, Earth and Heaven. Next: HYMN XCIX. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: FOR Jātavedas let us press the Soma: may he consume the wealth of the malignant. May Agni carry us through all our troubles, through grief as in a boat across the river. Next: HYMN C. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: MAY he who hath his home with strength, the Mighty, the King supreme of earth and spacious heaven, Lord of true power, to he invoked in battles,—may Indra, girt by Maruts, be our succour.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whose way is unattainable like Sūrya's: he in each fight is the strong Vṛtra-slayer, Mightiest with his Friends in his own courses. May Indra, girt by Maruts, be our succour.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whose paths go forth in their great might resistless, forthmilking, as it were, heaven's genial moisture. With manly strength triumphant, foe-subduer,—may Indra, girt by Maruts, be our succour.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Among Aṅgirases he was the chiefest, a Friend with friends, mighty amid the mighty. Praiser mid praisers, honoured most of singers. May Indra, girt by Maruts, be our succour.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Strong with the Rudras as with his own children, in manly battle conquering his foemen ' With his close comrades doing deeds of glory,—may Indra, girt by Maruts, be our succour.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Humbler of pride, exciter of the conflict, the Lord of heroes, God invoked of many, May he this day gain with our men the sunlight. May Indra, girt by Maruts, be our succour.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: His help hath made him cheerer in the battle, the folk have made him guardian of their comfort. Sole Lord is he of every holy service. May Indra, girt by Maruts, be our succour.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To him the Hero, on high days of prowess, heroes for help and booty shall betake them. He hath found light even in the blinding darkness. May Indra, girt by Maruts, be our succour.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He with his left hand checketh even the mighty, and with his right hand gathereth up the booty. Even with the humble he acquireth riches. May Indra, girt by Maruts, be our succour.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With hosts on foot and cars he winneth treasures: well is he known this day by all the people. With manly might he conquereth those who hate him. May Indra, girt by Maruts, be our succour.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When in his ways with kinsmen or with strangers he speedeth to the fight, invoked of many, For gain of waters, and of sons and grandsons, may Indra, girt by Maruts, be our succour.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Awful and fierce, fiend-slayer, thunder-wielder, with boundless knowledge, hymned by hundreds, mighty, In strength like Soma, guard of the Five Peoples, may Indra, girt by Maruts, be our succour.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Winning the light, hitherward roars his thunder like the terrific mighty voice of Heaven. Rich gifts and treasures evermore attend him. May Indra, girt by Maruts, be our succour.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whose home eternal through his strength surrounds him on every side, his laud, the earth and heaven, May he, delighted with our service, save us. May Indra, girt by Maruts, be our succour.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The limit of whose power not Gods by Godhead, nor mortal men have reached, nor yet the Waters. Both Earth and Heaven in vigour he surpasseth. May Indra, girt by Maruts, he our succour.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The red and tawny mare, blaze-marked, high standing, celestial who, to bring Ṛjrāśva riches, Drew at the pole the chariot yoked with stallions, joyous, among the hosts of men was noted.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Vārṣāgiras unto thee, O Indra, the Mighty One, sing forth this laud to please thee, Ṛjrāśva with his fellows, Ambarīṣa, Surādhas, Sahadeva, Bhayamāna.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He, much invoked, hath slain Dasyus and Śimyus, after his wont, and laid them low with arrows. The mighty Thunderer with his fair-complexioned friends won the land, the sunlight, and the waters.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May Indra evermore be our protector, and unimperilled may we win the booty. This prayer of ours may Varuṇa grant, and Mitra, and Aditi and Sindhu, Earth and Heaven. Next: HYMN CI. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: SING, with oblation, praise to him who maketh glad, who with Ṛjiśvan drove the dusky brood away. Fain for help, him the strong whose right hand wields the bolt, him girt by Maruts we invoke to be our Friend.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra, who with triumphant wrath smote Vyaṁsa down, and Śambara, and Pipru the unrighteous one; Who extirpated Śuṣṇa the insatiate,—him girt by Maruts we invoke to be our Friend.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He whose great work of manly might is heaven and earth, and Varuṇa and Sūrya keep his holy law; Indra, whose law the rivers follow as they flow,—him girt by Maruts we invoke to be our Friend.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He who is Lord and Master of the steeds and kine, honoured—the firm and sure—at every holy act; Stayer even of the strong who pours no offering out,—him girt by Maruts we invoke to be our Friend.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He who is Lord of all the world that moves and breathes, who for the Brahman first before all found the Cows; Indra who cast the Dasyus down beneath his feet,—him girt by Maruts we invoke to be our Friend.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whom cowards must invoke and valiant men of war, invoked by those who conquer and by those who flee; Indra, to whom all beings turn their constant thought,—him girt by Maruts we invoke to be our Friend.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Refulgent in the Rudras’ region he proceeds, and with the Rudras through the wide space speeds the Dame. The hymn of praise extols Indra the far-renowned: him girt by Maruts we invoke to be our Friend.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O girt by Maruts, whether thou delight thee in loftiest gathering-place or lowly dwelling, Come thence unto our rite, true boon-bestower: through love of thee have we prepared oblations.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We, fain for thee, strong Indra, have pressed Soma, and, O thou sought with prayer, have made oblations. Now at this sacrifice, with all thy Maruts, on sacred grass, O team-borne God, rejoice thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Rejoice thee with thine own Bay Steeds, O Indra, unclose thy jaws and let thy lips be open. Thou with the fair cheek, let thy Bay Steeds bring thee: gracious to us, he pleased with our oblation.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Guards of the camp whose praisers are the Maruts, may we through Indra, get ourselves the booty. This prayer of ours may Varuṇa grant, and Mitra, and Aditi and Sindhu, Earth and Heaven. Next: HYMN CII. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To thee the Mighty One I bring this mighty hymn, for thy desire hath been gratified by my laud. In Indra, yea in him victorious through his strength, the Gods have joyed at feast and when the Soma flowed.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Seven Rivers bear his glory far and wide, and heaven and sky and earth display his comely form. The Sun and Moon in change alternate run their course, that we, O Indra, may behold and may have faith.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Maghavan, grant us that same car to bring us spoil, thy conquering car in which we joy in shock of fight. Thou, Indra, whom our hearts praise highly in the war, grant shelter, Maghavan, to us who love thee well.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Encourage thou our side in every fight: may we, with thee for our ally, conquer the foeman's host. Indra, bestow on us joy and felicity break down, O Maghavan, the vigour of our foes.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For here in divers ways these men invoking thee, holder of treasures, sing hymns to win thine aid. Ascend the car that thou mayest bring spoil to us, for, Indra, thy fixt winneth the victory.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: His arms win kine, his power is boundless in each act best, with a hundred helps, waker of battle's din Is Indra: none may rival him in mighty strength. Hence, eager for the spoil the people call on him.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thy glory, Maghavan, exceeds a hundred yea, more than a hundred, than a thousand mid the folk, The great bowl hath inspirited thee boundlessly: so mayst thou slay the Vṛtras, breaker-down of forts!

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Of thy great might there is a three counterpart, the three earths, Lord men and the three realms of light. Above this whole world, Indra, thou hast waxen great: without a foe art thou, nature, from of old.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We invocate thee first among the Deities: thou hast become a mighty Conquer in fight. May Indra fill with spirit this our singer's heart, and make our car impetuous, foremost in attack.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou hast prevailed, and hast not kept the booty back, in trifling battles in those of great account. We make thee keen, the Mighty One, succour us: inspire us, Maghavan, when we defy the foe.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May Indra evermore be our Protector, and unimperilled may we win the booty. This prayer of ours may Varuṇa grant and Mitra, and Aditi and Sindhu, Earth and Heaven. Next: HYMN CIII. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: THAT highest Indra-power of thine is distant: that which is here sages possessed aforetime. This one is on the earth, in heaven the other, and both unite as flag with flag in battle.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He spread the wide earth out and firmly fixed it, smote with his thunderbolt and loosed the waters. Maghavan with his puissance struck down Ahi, rent Rauhiṇa to death and slaughtered Vyaṁsa.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Armed with his bolt and trusting in his prowess he wandered shattering the forts of Dāsas. Cast thy dart, knowing, Thunderer, at the Dasyu; increase the Ārya's might and glory, Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For him who thus hath taught these human races, Maghavan, bearing a fame-worthy title, Thunderer, drawing nigh to slay the Dasyus, hath given himself the name of Son for glory.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: See this abundant wealth that he possesses, and put your trust in Indra's hero vigour. He found the cattle, and he found the horses, he found the plants, the forests and the waters.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To him the truly strong, whose deeds are many, to him the strong Bull let us pour the Soma. The Hero, watching like a thief in ambush, goes parting the possessions of the godless.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Well didst thou do that hero deed, O Indra, in waking with thy bolt the slumbering Ahi. in thee, delighted, Dames divine rejoiced them, the flying Maruts and all Gods were joyful.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As thou hast smitten Śuṣṇa, Pipru, Vṛtra and Kuyava, and Śambara's forts , O Indra. This prayer of ours may Varuṇa grant, and Mitra, and Aditi and Sindhu, Earth and Heaven. Next: HYMN CIV. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: THE altar hath been made for thee to rest on: come like a panting courser and be seated. Loosen thy flying Steeds, set free thy Horses who bear thee swiftly nigh at eve and morning.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: These men have come to Indra for assistance: shall he not quickly come upon these pathways? May the Gods quell the fury of the Dāsa, and may they lead our folk to happy fortune.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He who hath only wish as his possession casts on himself, casts foam amid the waters. Both wives of Kuyava in milk have bathed them: may they be drowned within the depth of Śiphā.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This hath his kinship checked who lives beside us: with ancient streams forth speeds and rules the Hero, Añjasī, Kuliśī, and Virapatnī, delighting him, bear milk upon their waters.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Soon as this Dasyu's traces were discovered, as she who knows her home, he sought the dwelling. Now think thou of us, Maghavan, nor cast us away as doth a profligate his treasure.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra, as such, give us a share of sunlight, of waters, sinlessness, and reputation. Do thou no harm to our yet unborn offspring: our trust is in thy mighty Indra-power.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Now we, I think, in thee as such have trusted: lead us on, Mighty One, to ample riches. In no unready house give us, O Indra invoked of many, food and drink when hungry.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Slay us not, Indra; do not thou forsake us: steal not away the joys which we delight in. Rend not our unborn brood, strong Lord of Bounty! our vessels with the life that is within them.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come to us; they have called thee Soma-lover: here is the pressed juice. Drink thereof for rapture. Widely-capacious, pour it down within thee, and, invocated, hear us like a Father. Next: HYMN CV. Viśvedevas.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: WITHIN the waters runs the Moon, he with the beauteous wings in heaven. Ye lightnings with your golden wheels, men find not your abiding-place. Mark this my woe, ye Earth and Heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Surely men crave and gain their wish. Close to her husband clings the wife. And, in embraces intertwined, both give and take the bliss of love. Mark this my woe, ye Earth and Heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O never may that light, ye Gods, fall from its station in the sky. Ne’er fail us one like Soma sweet, the spring of our felicity. Mark this my woe , ye Earth and Heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I ask the last of sacrifice. As envoy he shall tell it forth. Where is the ancient law divine? Who is its new diffuser now? Mark this my woe, ye Earth and Heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ye Gods who yonder have your home in the three lucid realms of heaven, What count ye truth and what untruth? Where is mine ancient call on you? Mark this my woe, ye Earth and Heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: What is your firm support of Law? What Varuṇa's observant eye? How may we pass the wicked on the path of mighty Aryaman? Mark this my woe, ye Earth and Heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I am the man who sang of old full many a laud when Soma flowed. Yet torturing cares consume me as the wolf assails the thirsty deer. Mark this my woe, ye Earth and Heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Like rival wives on every side enclosing ribs oppress me sore. O Śatakratu, biting cares devour me, singer of thy praise, as rats devour the weaver's threads. Mark this my woe, ye Earth and Heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Where those seven rays are shining, thence my home and family extend. This Tṛta Āptya knoweth well, and speaketh out for brotherhood. Mark this my woe, ye Earth and Heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May those five Bulls which stand on high full in the midst of mighty heaven, Having together swiftly borne my praises to the Gods, return. Mark this my woe, ye Earth and Heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: High in the mid ascent of heaven those Birds of beauteous pinion sit. Back from his path they drive the wolf as he would cross the restless floods. Mark this my woe, ye Earth and Heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Firm is this new-wrought hymn of praise, and meet to be told forth, O Gods. The flowing of the floods is Law, Truth is the Sun's extended light. Mark this my woe, ye Earth and Heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Worthy of laud, O Agni, is that kinship which thou hast with Gods. Here seat thee like a man: most wise, bring thou the Gods for sacrifice. Mark this my woe, ye Earth and Heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Here seated, man-like as a priest shall wisest Agni to the Gods Speed onward our oblations, God among the Gods, intelligent. Mark this my woe, ye Earth and Heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Varuṇa makes the holy prayer. To him who finds the path we pray. He in the heart reveals his thought. Let sacred worship rise anew. Mark this my woe, ye Earth and Heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: That pathway of the Sun in heaven, made to be highly glorified, Is not to be transgressed, O Gods. O mortals, ye behold it not. Mark this my woe, ye Earth and Heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Tṛta, when buried in the well, calls on the Gods to succour him. That call of his Bṛhaspati heard and released him from distress. Mark this my woe, ye Earth and Heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: A ruddy wolf beheld me once, as I was faring on my path. He, like a carpenter whose back is aching crouched and slunk away. Mark this my woe, ye Earth and Heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Through this our song may we, allied with Indra, with all our heroes conquer in the battle. This prayer of ours may Varuṇa grant, and Mitra, and Aditi and Sindhu, Earth and Heaven. Next: HYMN CVI. Viśvedevas.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: CALL we for aid on Indra, Mitra, Varuṇa and Agni and the Marut host and Aditi. Even as a chariot from a difficult ravine, bountiful Vasus, rescue us from all distress.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come ye Ādityas for our full prosperity, in conquests of the foe, ye Gods, bring joy to us. Even as a chariot from a difficult ravine, bountiful Vasus, rescue us from all distress.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May the most glorious Fathers aid us, and the two Goddesses, Mothers of the Gods, who strengthen Law. Even as a chariot from a difficult ravine, bountiful Vasus, rescue us from all distress.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To mighty Narāśaṁsa, strengthening his might, to Pūṣan, ruler over men, we pray with hymns. Even as a chariot from a difficult ravine, bountiful Vasus, rescue us from all distress.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Bṛhaspati, make us evermore an easy path: we crave what boon thou hast for men in rest and stir. Like as a chariot from a difficult ravine, bountiful Vasus, rescue us from all distress.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Sunk in the pit the Ṛṣi Kutsa called, to aid, Indra the Vṛtra-slayer, Lord of power and might. Even as a chariot from a difficult ravine, bountiful Vasus, rescue us from all distress.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May Aditi the Goddess guard us with the Gods: may the protecting God keep us with ceaseless care. This prayer of ours may Varuṇa grant, and Mitra, and Aditi and Sindhu, Earth and Heaven. Next: HYMN CVII. Viśvedevas.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: THE sacrifice obtains the Gods’ acceptance: be graciously inclined to us, Ādityas. Hitherward let your favour be directed, and be our best deliverer from trouble.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: By praise-songs of Aṅgirases exalted, may the Gods come to us with their protection. May Indra with his powers, Maruts with Maruts, Aditi with Ādityas grant us shelter.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This laud of ours may Varuṇa and Indra, Aryaman Agni, Savitar find pleasant. This prayer of ours may Varuṇa grant, and Mitra, and Aditi and Sindhu, Earth and Heaven. Next: HYMN CVIII. Indra-Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: ON that most wondrous car of yours, O Indra and Agni, which looks round on all things living, Take ye your stand and come to us together, and drink libations of the flowing Soma.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As vast as all this world is in its compass, deep as it is, with its far-stretching surface, So let this Soma be, Indra and Agni, made for your drinking till your soul be sated.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For ye have won a blessed name together: yea, with one aim ye strove, O Vṛtra-slayers. So Indra-Agni, seated here together, pour in, ye Mighty Ones, the mighty Soma.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Both stand adorned, when fires are duly kindled, spreading the sacred grass, with lifted ladles. Drawn by strong Soma juice poured forth around us, come, Indra-Agni, and display your favour.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The brave deeds ye have done, Indra and Agni, the forms ye have displayed and mighty exploits, The ancient and auspicious bonds of friendship,—for sake of these drink of the flowing Soma.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As first I said when choosing you, in battle we must contend with Asuras for this Soma. So came ye unto this my true conviction, and drank libations of the flowing Soma.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: If in your dwelling, or with prince or Brahman, ye, Indra-Agni, Holy Ones, rejoice you, Even from thence, ye mighty Lords, come hither, and drink libation of the flowing Soma.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: If with, the Yadus, Turvaśas, ye sojourn, with Druhyus, Anus, Pūrus, Indra-Agni! Even from thence, ye mighty Lords, come hither, and drink libations of the flowing Soma.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whether, O Indra-Agni, ye be dwelling in lowest earth, in central, or in highest. Even from thence, ye mighty Lords, come hither, and drink libations of the flowing Soma.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whether, O Indra-Agni, ye be dwelling in highest earth, in central, or in lowest, Even from thence, ye mighty Lords, come hither, and drink libations of the flowing Soma.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whether ye be in heaven, O Indra-Agni, on earth, on mountains, in the herbs, or waters, Even from thence, ye mighty Lords, come hither, and drink libations of the flowing Soma.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: If, when the Sun to the mid-heaven hath mounted, ye take delight in food, O Indra-Agni, Even from thence, ye mighty Lords, come hither, and drink libations of the flowing Soma.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thus having drunk your fill of our libation, win us all kinds of wealth, Indra and Agni. This prayer of ours may Varuṇa grant, and Mitra, and Aditi and Sindhu, Earth and Heaven. Next: HYMN CIX. Indra-Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: LONGING for weal I looked around, in spirit, for kinsmen, Indra-Agni, or for brothers. No providence but yours alone is with me so have I wrought for you this hymn for succour.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For I have heard that ye give wealth more freely than worthless son-in-law or spouse's brother. So offering to you this draught of Soma, I make you this new hymn, Indra and Agni,

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Let us not break the cords: with this petition we strive to gain the powers of our forefathers. For Indra-Agni the strong drops are joyful, for here in the bowl's lap are both the press-stones.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For you the bowl divine, Indra and Agni, presses the Soma gladly to delight you. With hands auspicious and fair arms, ye Aśvins, haste, sprinkle it with sweetness in the waters.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: You, I have heard, were mightiest, Indra-Agni, when Vṛtra fell and when the spoil was parted. Sit at this sacrifice, ye ever active, on the strewn grass, and with the juice delight you.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Surpassing all men where they shout for battle, ye Twain exceed the earth and heaven in greatness. Greater are ye than rivers and than mountains, O Indra-Agni, and all things beside them.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Bring wealth and give it, ye whose arms wield thunder: Indra and Agni, with your powers protect us. Now of a truth these be the very sunbeams wherewith our fathers were of old united.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Give, ye who shatter forts, whose hands wield thunder: Indra and Agni, save us in our battles. This prayer of ours may Varuṇa grant, and Mitra, and Aditi and Sindhu, Earth and Heaven. Next: HYMN CX. Ṛbhus.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: THE holy work I wrought before is wrought again: my sweetest hymn is sung to celebrate your praise. Here, O ye Ṛbhus, is this sea for all the Gods: sate you with Soma offered with the hallowing word.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When, seeking your enjoyment onward from afar, ye, certain of my kinsmen, wandered on your way, Sons of Sudhanvan, after your long journeying, ye came unto the home of liberal Savitar.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Savitar therefore gave you immortality, because ye came proclaiming him whom naught can hide; And this the drinking-chalice of the Asura, which till that time was one, ye made to be fourfold.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When they had served with zeal at sacrifice as priests, they, mortal as they were, gained immortality. The Ṛbhus, children of Sudhanvan, bright as suns, were in a year's course made associate with prayers.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Ṛbhus, with a rod measured, as ’twere a field, the single sacrificial chalice. wide of mouth, Lauded of all who saw, praying for what is best, desiring glorious fame among Immortal Gods.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As oil in ladles, we through knowledge will present unto the Heroes of the firmament our hymn,— The Ṛbhus who came near with this great Father's speed, and rose to heaven's high sphere to eat the strengthening food.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
