text: Heard is the roar of the advancing Maruts, terrific, glittering, and swiftly moving, Who with their rush o’erthrow as ’twere a sinner the mortal who would fight with those who love him

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Give to the Mānas, Indra with Maruts, gifts universal, gifts of cattle foremost. Thou, God, art praised with Gods who must be lauded. May we find strengthening food in full abundance. Next: HYMN CLXX. Indra. Maruts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: NAUGHT is to-day, to-morrow naught. Who comprehends the mystery? We must address ourselves unto another's thought, and lost is then the hope we formed.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Maruts are thy brothers. Why, O Indra, wouldst thou take our lives? Agree with them in friendly wise, and do not slay us in the fight.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agastya, brother, why dost thou neglect us, thou who art our friend? We know the nature of thy mind. Verity thou wilt give us naught.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Let them prepare the altar, let them kindle fire in front: we two Here will spread sacrifice for thee, that the Immortal may observe.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou, Lord of Wealth, art Master of all treasures, thou, Lord of friends, art thy friends' best supporter. O Indra, speak thou kindly with the Maruts, and taste oblations in their proper season. Next: HYMN CLXXI. Maruts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To you I come with this mine adoration, and with a hymn I crave the Strong Ones' favour A hymn that truly makes you joyful, Maruts. Suppress your anger and unyoke your horses.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Maruts, to you this laud with prayer and worship, formed in the mind and heart, ye Gods, is offered. Come ye to us, rejoicing in your spirit, for ye are they who make our prayer effective.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Maruts, praised by us, shall show us favour; Maghavan, lauded, shall be most propitious. Maruts,, may all our days that are to follow be very pleasant, lovely and triumphant.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I fled in terror from this mighty Indra, my body trembling in alarm, O Maruts. Oblations meant for you had been made ready; these have we set aside: for this forgive us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: By whom the Mānas recognize the day-springs, by whose strength at the dawn of endless mornings, Give us, thou Mighty, glory with Maruts. fierce with the fierce, the Strong who givest triumph.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Do thou, O Indra, guard the conquering Heroes, and rid thee of thy wrath against the Maruts, With them, the wise, victorious and bestowing. May we find strengthening food in full abundance. Next: HYMN CLXXII. Maruts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: WONDERFUL let your coming be, wondrous with help, ye Bounteous Ones, Maruts, who gleam as serpents gleam.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Far be from us, O Maruts, ye free givers, your impetuous shaft; Far from us be the stone ye hurl.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Bounteous Givers, touch ye not, O Maruts, Tṛṇskanda's folk; Lift ye us up that we may live. Next: HYMN CLXXIII. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: THE praise-song let him sing forth bursting bird-like: sing we that hymn which like heaven's light expandeth, That the milk-giving cows may, unimpeded call to the sacred grass the Gods’ assembly.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Let the Bull sing with Bulls whose toil is worship, with a loud roar like some wild beast that hungers. Praised God! the glad priest brings his heart's devotion; the holy youth presents twofold oblation.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May the Priest come circling the measured stations, and with him bring the earth's autumnal fruitage. Let the Horse neigh led near, let the Steer bellow: let the Voice go between both worlds as herald,

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To him we offer welcomest oblations, the pious bring their strength-inspiring praises. May Indra, wondrous in his might, accept them, car-borne and swift to move like the Nāsatyas.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Praise thou that Indra who is truly mighty, the car-borne Warrior, Maghavan the Hero; Stronger in war than those who fight against him, borne by strong steeds, who kills enclosing darkness;

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Him who surpasses heroes in his greatness: the earth and heavens suffice not for his girdles. Indra endues the earth to be his garment, and, God-like, wears the heaven as ’twere a frontlet,

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thee, Hero, guardian of the brave in battles, who roamest in the van,—to draw thee hither, Indra, the hosts agree beside the Soma, and joy, for his great actions, in the Chieftain.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Libations in the sea to thee are pleasant, when thy divine Floods come to cheer these people. To thee the Cow is sum of all things grateful when with the wish thou seekest men and princes.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So may we in this One be well befriended, well aided as it were through praise of chieftains, That Indra still may linger at our worship, as one led swift to work, to hear our praises.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Like men in rivalry extolling princes, our Friend be Indra, wielder of the thunder. Like true friends of some city's lord within them held in good rule with sacrifice they help him.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For every sacrifice makes Indra stronger, yea, when he goes around angry in spirit; As pleasure at the ford invites the thirsty, as the long way brings him who gains his object.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Let us not here contend with Gods, O Indra, for here, O Mighty One, is thine own portion, The Great, whose Friends the bounteous Maruts honour, as with a stream, his song who pours oblations.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Addressed to thee is this our praise, O Indra: Lord of Bay Steeds, find us hereby advancement. So mayst thou lead us on, O God, to comfort. May we find strengthening food in full abundance. Next: HYMN CLXXIV. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: THOU art the King of all the Gods, O Indra: protect the men, O Asura, preserve us. Thou Lord of Heroes, Maghavan, our saver, art faithful, very rich, the victory-giver.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra, thou humbledst tribes that spake with insult by breaking down seven autumn forts, their refuge. Thou stirredst, Blameless! billowy floods, and gavest his foe a prey to youthful Purukutsa.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With whom thou drivest troops whose lords are heroes, and bringest daylight now, much worshipped Indra, With them guard lion-like wasting active Agni to dwell in our tilled fields and in our homestead.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: They through the greatness of thy spear, O Indra, shall, to thy praise, rest in this earthly station. To loose the floods, to seek, for kine, the battle, his Bays he mounted boldly seized the booty.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra, bear Kutsa, him in whom thou joyest: the dark-red horses of the Wind are docile. Let the Sun roll his chariot wheel anear us, and let the Thunderer go to meet the foemen.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou Indra, Lord of Bays, made strong by impulse, hast slain the vexers of thy friends, who give not. They who beheld the Friend beside the living were cast aside by thee as they rode onward.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra, the bard sang forth in inspiration: thou madest earth a covering for the Dāsa. Maghavan made the three that gleam with moisture, and to his home brought Kuyavāc to slay him.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: These thine old deeds new bards have sung, O Indra. Thou conqueredst, boundest many tribes for ever. Like castles thou hast crushed the godless races, and bowed the godless scorner's deadly weapon.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: A Stormer thou hast made the stormy waters flow down, O Indra, like the running rivers. When o’er the flood thou broughtest them, O Hero, thou keptest Turvaśa and Yadu safely.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra, mayst thou be ours in all occasions, protector of the men, most gentle-hearted, Giving us victory over all our rivals. May we find strengthening food in full abundance. Next: HYMN CLXXV. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: GLAD thee: thy glory hath been quaffed, Lord of Bay Steeds, as ’twere the bowl's enlivening mead. For thee the Strong there is strong drink, mighty, omnipotent to win.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Let our strong drink, most excellent, exhilarating, come to thee, Victorious, Indra! bringing gain, immortal conquering in fight,

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou, Hero, winner of the spoil, urgest to speed the car of man. Burn, like a vessel with the flame, the lawless Dasyu, Conqueror!

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Empowered by thine own might, O Sage, thou stolest Sūrya's chariot wheel. Thou barest Kutsa with the steeds of Wind to Śuṣṇa as his death.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Most mighty is thy rapturous joy, most splendid is thine active power, Wherewith, foe-slaying, sending bliss, thou art supreme in gaining steeds.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As thou, O Indra, to the ancient singers wast ever joy, as water to the thirsty, So unto thee I sing this invocation. May we find strengthening food in full abundance. Next: HYMN CLXXVI. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: CHEER thee with draughts to win us bliss: Soma, pierce Indra in thy strength. Thou stormest trembling in thy rage, and findest not a foeman nigh.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Make our songs penetrate to him who is the Only One of men; For whom the sacred food is spread, as the steer ploughs the barley in.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Within whose hands deposited all the Five Peoples’ treasures rest. Mark thou the man who injures us and kill him like the heavenly bolt.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Slay everyone who pours no gift, who, hard to reach, delights thee not. Bestow on us what wealth he hath: this even the worshipper awaits.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou helpest him the doubly strong whose hymns were sung unceasingly. When Indra fought, O Soma, thou helpest the mighty in the fray.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As thou, O Indra, to the ancient singers wast ever joy, like water to the thirsty, So unto thee I sing this invocation. May we find strengthening food in full abundance. Next: HYMN CLXXVII. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: THE Bull of men, who cherishes all people, King of the Races, Indra, called of many, Fame-loving, praised, hither to me with succour turn having yoked both vigorous Bay Horses!

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thy mighty Stallions, yoked by prayer, O Indra, thy. Coursers to thy mighty chariot harnessed,— Ascend thou these, and borne by them come hither: with Soma juice outpoured, Indra, we call thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ascend thy mighty car: the mighty Soma is poured for thee and sweets are sprinkled round us. Come down to us-ward, Bull of human races, come, having harnessed them, with strong Bay Horses.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Here is God-reaching sacrifice, here the victim; here, Indra, are the prayers, here is the Soma. Strewn is the sacred grass: come hither, Śakra; seat thee and drink: unyoke thy two Bay Coursers.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come to us, Indra, come thou highly lauded to the devotions of the singer Māna. Singing, may we find early through thy succour, may we find strengthening food in full abundance. Next: HYMN CLXXVIII. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: IF, Indra, thou hast given that gracious hearing where with thou helpest those who sang thy praises. Blast not the wish that would exalt us may I gain all from thee, and pay all man's devotions.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Let not the Sovran Indra disappoint us in what shall bring both Sisters to our dwelling. To him have run the quickly flowing waters. May Indra come to us with life and friendship.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Victorious with the men, Hero in battles, Indra, who hears the singer's supplication, Will bring his car nigh to the man who offers, if he himself upholds the songs that praise him.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Yea, Indra, with the men, through love of glory consumes the sacred food which friends have offered. The ever-strengthening song of him who worships is sung in fight amid the clash of voices.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Aided by thee, O Maghavan, O Indra, may we subdue our foes who count them mighty. Be our protector, strengthen and increase us. May we find strengthening food in full abundance. Next: HYMN CLXXIX. Rati.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: 'Through many autumns have I toiled and laboured, at night and morn, through age-inducing dawnings. Old age impairs the beauty of our bodies. Let husbands still come near unto their spouses.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For even the men aforetime, law-fulfillers, who with the Gods declared eternal statutes,— They have decided, but have not accomplished: so now let Wives come near unto their husbands.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Non inutilis est labor cui Dii favent: nos omnes aemulos et aemulas vincamus. Superemus in hac centum artium pugna in qua duas partes convenientes utrinque commovemus.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Cupido me cepit illius tauri [viri] qui me despicit, utrum hinc utrum illinc ab aliqua parte nata sit. Lopamudra taurum [maritum suum] ad se detrahit: insipiens illa sapientem anhelantem absorbet.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This Soma I address that is most near us, that which hath been imbibed within the spirit, To pardon any sins we have committed. Verily mortal man is full of longings.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agastya thus, toiling with strong endeavour, wishing for children, progeny and power, Cherished—a sage of mighty strength—both classes, and with the Gods obtained his prayer's fulfilment. By 'both classes' probably priests and princes, or institutors of sacrifices, are meant. M. Bergaigne understands the expression to mean the two forms or essences of Soma, the celestial and the terrestrial. Next: HYMN CLXXX. Aśvins.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: LIGHTLY your coursers travel through the regions when round the sea of air your car is flying. Your golden fellies scatter drops of moisture: drinking the sweetness ye attend the Mornings.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ye as ye travel overtake the Courser who flies apart, the Friend of man, most holy. The prayer is that the Sister may convey you, all praised, meath-drinkers! to support and strengthen.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ye have deposited, matured within her, in the raw cow the first milk of the milch-cow, Which the bright offerer, shining like a serpent mid trees, presents to you whose form is perfect.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ye made the fierce heat to be full of sweetness for Atri at his wish, like streaming water. Fire-offering thence is yours, O Aśvins, Heroes: your car-wheels speed to us like springs of honey.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Like Tugra's ancient son may I, ye Mighty, bring you to give your gifts with milk-oblations. Your greatness compasseth Earth, Heaven, and Waters: decayed for you is sorrow's net, ye Holy.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When, Bounteous Ones, ye drive your yoked team downward, ye send, by your own natures, understanding. Swift as the wind let the prince please and feast you: he, like a pious man, gains strength for increase.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For verily we truthful singers praise you the niggard trafficker is here excluded. Now, even now do ye O blameless Aśvins, ye Mighty, guard the man whose God is near him.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: You of a truth day after day, O Aśvins, that he might win the very plenteous torrent, Agastya, famous among mortal heroes, roused with a thousand lauds like sounds of music.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When with the glory of your car ye travel, when we go speeding like the priest of mortals, And give good horses to sacrificers, may we, Nāsatyas! gain our share of riches.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With songs of praise we call to-day, O Aśvins, that your new chariot, for our own well-being, That circles heaven with never-injured fellies. May we find strengthening food in full abundance. Next: HYMN CLXXXI. Aśvins

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: WHAT, dearest Pair, is this in strength and riches that ye as Priests are bring from the waters? This sacrifice is your glorification, ye who protect mankind and give them treasures.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May your pure steeds, rain-drinkers, bring you hither, swift as the tempest, your celestial coursers, Rapid as thought, with fair backs, full of vigour, resplendent in their native light, O Aśvins.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Your car is like a torrent rushing downward: may it come nigh, broad-seated, for our welfare,— Car holy, strong, that ever would be foremost, thought-swift, which ye, for whom we long, have mounted.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Here sprung to life, they both have sung together, with bodies free from stain, with signs that mark them; One of you Prince of Sacrifice, the Victor, the other counts as Heaven's auspicious offspring.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May your car-seat, down-gliding, golden-coloured, according to your wish approach our dwellings. Men shall feed full the bay steeds of the other, and, Aśvins they with roars shall stir the regions.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Forth comes your strong Bull like a cloud of autumn, sending abundant food of liquid sweetness. Let them feed with the other's ways and vigour: the upper streams have come and do us service.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Your constant song hath been sent forth, Disposers! that flows threefold in mighty strength, O Aśvins. Thus lauded, give the suppliant protection moving or resting hear mine invocation.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This song of bright contents for you is swelling in the men's hall where three-fold grass is ready. Your strong rain-cloud, ye Mighty Ones, hath swollen, honouring men as ’twere with milk's outpouring.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The prudent worshipper, like Pūṣan, Aśvins! praises you as he praises Dawn and Agni, When, singing with devotion, he invokes you. May we find strengthening food in full abundance. Next: HYMN CLXXXII. Aśvins.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: THIS was the task. Appear promptly, ye prudent Ones. Here is the chariot drawn by strong steeds: be ye glad. Heart-stirring, longed for, succourers of Viśpalā, here are Heaven's Sons whose sway blesses the pious man.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Longed for, most Indra-like, mighty, most Marut-like, most wonderful in deed, car-borne, best charioteers, Bring your full chariot hither heaped with liquid sweet: thereon, ye Aśvins, come to him who offers gifts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: What make ye there, ye Mighty? Wherefore linger ye with folk who, offering not, are held in high esteem? Pass over them; make ye the niggard's life decay: give light unto the singer eloquent in praise.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Crunch up on. every side the dogs who bark at us: slay ye our foes, O Aśvins this ye understand. Make wealthy every word of him who praises you: accept with favour, both Nāsatyas, this my laud.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ye made for Tugra's son amid the water-floods that animated ship with wings to fly withal, Whereon with God-devoted mind ye brought him forth, and fled with easy flight from out the mighty surge.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Four ships most welcome in the midst of ocean, urged by the Aśvins, save the son of Tugra, Him who was cast down headlong in the waters, plunged in the thick inevitable darkness.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: What tree was that which stood fixed in surrounding sea to which the son of Tugra supplicating clung? Like twigs, of which some winged creature may take hold, ye, Aśvins, bore him off safely to your renown.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Welcome to you be this the hymn of praises uttered by Mānas, O Nāsatyas, Heroes, From this our gathering where we offer Soma. May we find strengthening food in full abundance. Next: HYMN CLXXXIII. Aśvins.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: MAKE ready that which passes thought in swiftness, that hath three wheels and triple seat, ye Mighty, Whereon ye seek the dwelling of the pious, whereon, threefold, ye fly like birds with pinions.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Light rolls your easy chariot faring earthward, what time, for food, ye, full of wisdom, mount it. May this song, wondrous fair, attend your glory: ye, as ye travel, wait on Dawn Heaven's Daughter.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ascend your lightly rolling car, approaching the worshipper who turns him to his duties,— Whereon ye come unto the house to quicken man and his offspring, O Nāsatyas, Heroes.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Let not the wolf, let not the she-wolf harm you. Forsake me not, nor pass me by or others. Here stands your share, here is your hymn, ye Mighty: yours are these vessels, full of pleasant juices.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Gotama, Purumīlha, Atri bringing oblations all invoke you for protection. Like one who goes straight to the point directed, ye Nāsatyas, to mine invocation.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We have passed o’er the limit of this darkness: our praise hath been bestowed on you, O Aśvins. Come hitherward by paths which Gods have travelled. May we find strengthening food in full abundance. Next: HYMN CLXXXIV. Aśvins.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: LET us invoke you both this day and after the priest is here with lauds when morn is breaking: Nāsatyas, wheresoe’er ye be, Heaven's Children, for him who is more liberal than the godless.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With us, ye Mighty, let yourselves be joyful, glad in our stream of Soma slay the niggards. Graciously hear my hymns and invitations, marking, O Heroes, with your cars my longing.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Nāsatyas, Pūṣans, ye as Gods for glory arranged and set in order Sūrya's bridal. Your giant steeds move on, sprung from the waters, like ancient times of Varuṇa the Mighty.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Your grace be with us, ye who love sweet juices: further the hymn sung by the poet Māna, When men are joyful in your glorious actions, to win heroic strength, ye Bounteous Givers.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This praise was made, O liberal Lords, O Aśvins, for you with fair adornment by the Mānas. Come to our house for us and for our children, rejoicing, O Nāsatyas, in Agastya.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We have passed o’er the limit of this darkness: our praise hath been bestowed on you, O Aśvins. Come hitherward by paths which Gods have travelled. may we find strengthening food in full abundance. Next: HYMN CLXXXV. Heaven and Earth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: WHETHER of these is elder, whether later? How were they born? Who knoweth it, ye sages? These of themselves support all things existing: as on a car the Day and Night roll onward.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Twain uphold, though motionless and footless, a widespread offspring having feet and moving. Like your own son upon his parents’ bosom, protect us, Heaven and earth, from fearful danger.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I call for Aditi's unrivalled bounty, perfect, celestial, deathless, meet for worship. Produce this, ye Twain Worlds, for him who lauds you. Protect us, Heaven and Earth, from fearful danger.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May we be close to both the Worlds who suffer no pain, Parents of Gods, who aid with favour, Both mid the Gods, with Day and Night alternate. Protect us, Heaven and Earth, from fearful danger.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Faring together, young, with meeting limits, Twin Sisters lying in their Parents’ bosom, Kissing the centre of the world together. Protect us, Heaven and Earth, from fearful danger.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Duly I call the two wide seats, the mighty, the general Parents, with the God's protection. Who, beautiful to look on, make the nectar. Protect us, Heaven and Earth, from fearful danger.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Wide, vast, and manifold, whose bounds are distant,—these, reverent, I address at this our worship, The blessed Pair, victorious, all-sustaining. Protect us, Heaven and Earth, from fearful danger.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: What sin we have at any time committed against the Gods, our friend, our house's chieftain, Thereof may this our hymn be expiation. Protect us, Heaven and Earth, from fearful danger.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May both these Friends of man, who bless, preserve me, may they attend me with their help and favour. Enrich the man more liberal than the godless. May we, ye Gods, be strong with food rejoicing.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Endowed with understanding, I have uttered this truth, for all to hear, to Earth and Heaven. Be near us, keep us from reproach and trouble. Father and Mother, with your help preserve us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Be this my prayer fulfilled, O Earth and Heaven, wherewith, Father and Mother, I address you. Nearest of Gods be ye with your protection. May we find strengthening food in full abundance. Next: HYMN CLXXXVI. Viśvedevas.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: LOVED of all men, may Savitar, through praises offered as sacred food, come to our synod, That you too, through-our hymn, ye ever-youthful, may gladden, at your visit, all our people.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To us may all the Gods come trooped together, Aryaman, Mitra, Varuṇa concordant, That all may be promoters of our welfare, and with great might preserve our strength from slackness.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni I sing, the guest you love most dearly: the Conqueror through our lauds is friendly-minded. That he may be our Varuṇa rich in glory and send food like a prince praised by the godly.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To you I seek with reverence, Night and Morning, like a cow good to milk, with hope to conquer, Preparing on a common day the praise. song with milk of various hues within this udder.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May the great Dragon of the Deep rejoice us: as one who nourishes her young comes Sindhu, With whom we will incite the Child of Waters whom vigorous course swift as thought bring hither.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Moreover Tvaṣṭar also shall approach us, one-minded with the princes at his visit. Hither shall come the Vṛtra-slayer Indra, Ruler of men, as strongest of the Heroes.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Him too our hymns delight, that yoke swift horses, like mother cows who lick their tender youngling. To him our songs shall yield themselves like spouses, to him the most delightful of the Heroes.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So may the Maruts, armed with mighty weapons, rest here on heaven and earth with hearts in concord, As Gods whose cars have dappled steeds like torrents, destroyers of the foe allies of Mitra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: They hasten on to happy termination their orders when they are made known by glory. As on a fair bright day the arrow flieth o’er all the barren soil their missiles sparkle.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Incline the Aśvins to show grace, and Pūṣan, for power and might have they, their own possession. Friendly are Viṣṇu, Vāta, and Ṛbhukṣan so may I bring the Gods to make us happy.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This is my reverent thought of you, ye Holy; may it inspire you, make you dwell among us,— Thought, toiling for the Gods and seeking treasure. May we find strengthening food in full abundance. Next: HYMN CLXXXVII. Praise of Food.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Now will I glorify Food that upholds great strength, By whose invigorating power Trita rent Vṛtra limb from limb.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O pleasant Food, O Food of meath, thee have we chosen for our own, So be our kind protector thou.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come hitherward to us, O Food, auspicious with auspicious help, Health-bringing, not unkind, a dear and guileless friend.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: These juices which, O Food, are thine throughout the regions are diffused. like winds they have their place in heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: These gifts of thine, O Food, O Food most sweet to taste, These savours of thy juices work like creatures that have mighty necks.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: In thee, O Food, is set the spirit of great Gods. Under thy flag brave deeds were done he slew the Dragon with thy help.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: If thou be gone unto the splendour of the clouds, Even from thence, O Food of meath, prepared for our enjoyment, come.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whatever morsel we consume from waters or from plants of earth, O Soma, wax thou fat thereby.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: What Soma, we enjoy from thee in milky food or barley-brew, Vātāpi, grow thou fat thereby.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Vegetable, Cake of meal, he wholesome, firm, and strengthening: Vātāpi, grow thou fat thereby.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Food, from thee as such have we drawn forth with lauds, like cows, our sacrificial gifts, From thee who banquetest with Gods, from thee who banquetest with us. Next: HYMN CLXXXVIII. Āprīs.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: WINNER of thousands, kindled, thou shinest a God with Gods to-day. Bear out oblations, envoy, Sage.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Child of Thyself the sacrifice is for the righteous blent with meath, Presenting viands thousandfold.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Invoked and worthy of our praise bring Gods whose due is sacrifice: Thou, Agni, givest countless gifts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To seat a thousand Heroes they eastward have strewn the grass with might, Whereon, Ādityas, ye shine forth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The sovran all-imperial Doors, wide, good, many and manifold, Have poured their streams of holy oil.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With gay adornment, fair to see, in glorious beauty shine they forth: Let Night and Morning rest them here.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Let these two Sages first of all, heralds divine and eloquent, Perform for us this sacrifice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: You I address, Sarasvatī, and Bhāratī, and Iḷā, all: Urge ye us on to glorious fame.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Tvaṣṭar the Lord hath made all forms and all the cattle of the field Cause them to multiply for us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Send to the Gods, Vanaspati, thyself, the sacrificial draught: Let Agni make the oblations sweet.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni, preceder of the Gods, is honoured with the sacred song: He glows at offerings blest with Hail! Next: HYMN CLXXXIX. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: BY goodly paths lead us to riches, Agni, God who knowest every sacred duty. Remove the sin that makes us stray and wander. most ample adoration will we bring thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Lead us anew to happiness, O Agni; lead us beyond all danger and affliction. Be unto us a wide broad ample castle bless, prosper on their way our sons and offspring.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Far from us, Agni, put thou all diseases let them strike lauds that have no saving Agni. God, make our home again to be a blessing, with all the Immortal Deities, O Holy.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Preserve us, Agni, with perpetual succour, refulgent in the dwelling which thou lovest. O Conqueror, most youthful, let no danger touch him who praises thee to-day or after.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Give not us up a prey to sin, O Agni, the greedy enemy that brings us trouble; Not to the fanged that bites, not to the toothless: give not us up, thou Conqueror, to the spoiler.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Such as thou art, born after Law, O Agni when lauded give protection to our bodies, From whosoever would reproach or injure: for thou, God, rescuest from all oppression.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou, well discerning both these classes, comest to men at early morn, O holy Agni. Be thou obedient unto man at evening, to be adorned, as keen, by eager suitors.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To him have we addressed our pious speeches, I, Māna's son, to him victorious Agni. May we gain countless riches with the sages. May we find strengthening food in full abundance. Next: HYMN CXC. Bṛhaspati.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: GLORIFY thou Bṛhaspati, the scatheless, who must be praised with hymns, sweet-tongued and mighty, To whom as leader of the song, resplendent, worthy of lauds, both Gods and mortals listen.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: On him wait songs according to the season even as a stream of pious men set moving. Bṛhaspati—for he laid out the expanses—was, at the sacrifice, vast Mātariśvan.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The praise, the verse that offers adoration, may he bring forth, as the Sun sends his arms out, He who gives daily light through this God's wisdom, strong as a dread wild beast, and inoffensive.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: His song of praise pervades the earth and heaven: let the wise worshipper draw it, like a courser. These of Bṛhaspati, like hunters' arrows, go to the skies that change their hue like serpents.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Those, God, who count thee as a worthless bullock, and, wealthy sinners, live on thee the Bounteous,— On fools like these no blessing thou bestowest: Bṛhaspati, thou punishest the spiteful.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Like a fair path is he, where grass is pleasant, though hard to win, a Friend beloved most early. Those who unharmed by enemies behold us, while they would make them bare, stood closely compassed.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He to whom songs of praise go forth like torrents, as rivers eddying under banks flow sea-ward— Bṛhaspati the wise, the eager, closely looks upon both, the waters and the vessel.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So hath Bṛhaspati, great, strong and mighty, the God exceeding powerful, been brought hither. May he thus lauded give us kine and horses. May we find strengthening food in full abundance. Next: HYMN CXCI. Water. Grass. Sun.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: VENOMOUS, slightly venomous, or venomous aquatic worm,— Both creatures, stinging, unobserved, with poison have infected me.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Coming, it kills the unobserved; it kills them as it goes away, It kills them as it drives them off, and bruising bruises them to death.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Sara grass, Darbha, Kuśara, and Sairya, Muñja, Vīraṇa, Where all these creatures dwell unseen, with poison have infected me.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The cows had settled in their stalls, the beasts of prey had sought their lairs, Extinguished were the lights of men, when things unseen infected me.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Or these, these reptiles, are observed, like lurking thieves at evening time. Seers of all, themselves unseen: be therefore very vigilant.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Heaven is your Sire, your Mother Earth, Soma your Brother, Aditi Your Sister: seeing all, unseen, keep still and dwell ye happily.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Biters of shoulder or of limb, with needle-stings, most venomous, Unseen, whatever ye may be, vanish together and be gone.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Slayer of things unseen, the Sun, beheld of all, mounts, eastward, up, Consuming all that are not seen, and evil spirits of the night.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: There hath the Sun-God mounted up, who scorches much and everything. Even the Āditya from the hills, all-seen, destroying things unseen.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I hang the poison in the Sun, a wine-skin in a vintner's house, He will not die, nor shall we die: his path is far: he whom Bay Horses bear hath turned thee to sweet meath.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This little bird, so very small, hath swallowed all thy poison up. She will not die, nor shall we die: his path is far: he whom Bay Horses bear hath turned thee to sweet meath.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The three-times-seven bright sparks of fire have swallowed up the poison's strength. They will not die, nor shall we die: his path is far: he whom Bay Horses bear hath turned thee to sweet meath.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Of ninety rivers and of nine with power to stay the venom's course,— The names of all I have secured: his path is far: he whom Bay Horses bear hath turned thee to sweet meath.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So have the peahens three-times-seven, so have the maiden Sisters Seven Carried thy venom far away, as girls bear water in their jars.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The poison-insect is so small; I crush the creature with a stone. I turn the poison hence away, departed unto distant lands.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Forth issuing from the mountain's side the poison-insect spake and said: Scorpion, they venom is but weak. Next: HYMN I. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: THOU, mighty Agni, gatherest up all that is precious for thy friend. Bring us all treasures as thou art enkindled in libation's place

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Assemble, speak together: let your minds be all of one accord, As ancient Gods unanimous sit down to their appointed share.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The place is common, common the assembly, common the mind, so be their thought united. A common purpose do I lay before you, and worship with your general oblation.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: One and the same be your resolve, and be your minds of one accord. United be the thoughts of all that all may happily agree.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
